div.p: Medulla Novi Teſtamenti: THE SUBSTANCE OF THE NEW TESTAMENT, MORE ESPECIALLY Of the HISTORICAL; WITH A brief Account of the Doctrinal Part, in each Book, by way of Dialogue between a Divine and his Pariſhioner.

p.hi: Deſigned for the benefit of Private Families.

div.p: By THOMAS STANHOPE, Preacher at the Fleet.
London, Printed by A.G. and J. P. and are ſold by Nath. Rolles, at the Golden Key in St. Paul's Church-yard, 1680.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE Mrs. FANSHAW.
div.p:
I Know not what excuſe to make for offering ſo poor a Preſent to your Ladiſhip, and (under your Name) to the World. My performance muſt needs make it mean, though the Deſign is Great; it being a familiar Introduction to the underſtanding of the New Teſtament. But when I conſider what a Misfortune in your Education did caſt you
into a Religion, that can never hope to ſupport it ſelf but by Ignorance of the Scriptures, from which your Ladiſhip is now ſo happily delivered, through the aſſiſtance of that Eminent and Worthy Dean of Canterbury, to the Great Joy of your moſt Illuſtrious Brother the ever Renowned DUKE of Monmouth, his Grace; and to the Infinite ſatisfaction of your Huſband, who never thought himſelf completely Happy in you, till Religion had united your Souls, as well as Wedlock had done your Perſons. When I reflect on theſe things, I hope that (without accuſing you) I may fear that (till of late) you have been too much a Stranger to thoſe Holy Writings, or rather, they have been to you as a Sealed Book. And at the ſame time I may aſſure
my ſelf, that being brought into that Church which hath no other Rule or Standard of Faith but the Holy Scriptures, you will now Redeem the time of your Former Ignorance, by a ſtricter Application to that bleſſed Study, and therefore will not deſpiſe the meaneſt help which can be offered to you. I now preſent your Ladiſhip with my Endeavours about the New Teſtament, and hope ſhortly to give you an account of what I have already finiſhed concerning the Old. I have ſo perfect an aſſurance of your Ladiſhips Goodneſs, that I am confident you will eaſily pardon this Preſumption, and accept of my Faithful Zeal, and Hearty Prayers to God, to beſtow upon you all thoſe Bleſſings, which either your High Blood, or more
excellent Qualities may render you Capable of: and that you will permit me to aſſume the Honour, with the hearty wiſh of this, and many proſperous New Years, to own my ſelf,

closer.signed: Your Ladiſhips moſt humble Servant, THO. STANHOPE.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THis poor Book (long ſtrugling under Difficulties) would willingly have ſhewed it ſelf to the World in a larger Volume, and have given an account of the whole Scripture in one piece; but through ſeveral failures, it comes out but in part, i. e. the New Teſtament, which is now ſent forth to try how it will be Enter • ained. As to the promiſes of thoſe that are Dead I have nothing to mention; the feigned Endeavours of ſome now Living have ſufficiently hindred even this part of it. One Perſon aſſured me it ſhould be extant the latter end of Michaelmas Term, after that ſome time towards New-years tide, though nothing of that promiſe was kept. However it is now got abroad, and if it takes (as I hope it will) I ſhall be Encouraged to follow it with the other of the Old Teſtament in a ſhort time. Which done I ſhall have my End
propoſed, which is, to be God's and his Church's Servant, as an helper to the Common Salvation of Mankind. It may be neceſſary for Private Families. And ſome Judicious Perſons (particularly a moſt Learned Biſhop) have approved it. Young People may hereby be acquainted with the Holy Goſpel, and inſtructed in the Book and Chapter which they would have recourſe unto. In caſe it be frowned upon, I have the Confidence to believe none can blame me for my Deſign of doing Good. And I thank God for that univerſal Charity which he hath given me, that I heartily deſire the Temporal, Spiritual, and Eternal welfare of every Man in the World; whereunto I would contribute the utmoſt of my Endeavours, and for which, I would ſpend my Deareſt Blood. I have no more to add, but that I am not an Enemy to any one upon Earth, I heartily wiſh the Peace and Proſperity of all true Proteſtants; as the Friends of thoſe who love our Lord Jeſus; and to them I ſubſcribe my ſelf an hearty Servant for his bleſſed Name's ſake.

div.head: THE NEW TESTAMENT.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: WHy do you call this the New Teſtament?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Not only with reſpect to the Old, which preceded it, both in Order of Nature and Time; but alſo in regard that it declares God's gracious fulfilling the Conditions of the New Covenant (the Covenant of Grace, as the other was of Works) ſo far as concerned him.

p.hi: It ſeems then there were Two Covenants made with man.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There were ſo. The firſt (the Covenant of Works (before the Fall) the Condition whereof was Perfect Obedience; the Second, a Covenant of Grace (after the Fall) the Conditions whereof are Faith, and Sincere Obedience; the Mediator of which Covenant is Jeſus Chriſt, the Object of this New Teſtament.

p.hi: How is this New Teſtament divided?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Into Four Parts. 1. The Evangeliſts (i. e. their Writings.) 2. The Acts of the
Apostles. 3. The Canonical Epiſtles. 4. The Book of the Revelation.

p.hi: How many are there of the Evangeliſts?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They (and the Goſpels written by them) are Four, Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.

p.hi: Why call you thoſe Books Goſpels, and thoſe the Four Evangeliſts?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Greek Word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſignifies a Good Meſſage (and ſo the Evangeliſts are Meſſengers of Good Tidings) that Name ſuting beſt with theſe Writings, which contain an Hiſtory of what our Lord Chriſt did and ſuffered for the Salvation of Mankind. And the Engliſh, Goſpel, is thought to be quaſi Gods Spell, i.e. Gods Charm or Power, whereby he draws men to Life Eternal; ſo the Apoſtle explains it; I am not aſhamed of the Goſpel of Chriſt; Minſhew. for it is the power of God unto Salvation, Rom. 1, 16.

p.hi: Why were there ſeveral of them, and the whole not contracted into one Book?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God in his infinite Wiſdom did ſo order it; and more eſpecially for Two Reaſons. 1. To confirm the Truths contained in theſe Goſpels delivered by ſo many perſons. 2. That what one was not ſo exact in relating, the reſt, or at leaſt ſome of them might ſupply.

p.hi: How are theſe Evangeliſts (Prophetically) repreſented in the Old Teſtament?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Expoſitors do generally believe that they are ſhadowed out by the Four Living
Creatures in Ezekiel's Propheſie (Chap. 1.10.) which had Four Faces; one of a Man, the Second, of a Lion; the Third, of an Oxe; and the Fourth, of an Eagle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pray give me leave then to deſire you would ſatisfie me why the ſeveral Evangeliſts were thus repreſented; and how ſome ſmall Differences in their Writings are to be reconciled; and tell me what any one adds which is wanting in the others.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: This I ſhall willingly do, beginning with the Firſt in Order.

div.head: S. MATTHEW.

p.hi: HOw call you the firſt Goſpel in the New Teſtament?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is called the Goſpel of S. Matthew, the Evangeliſt.

p.hi: Why is it called by that Name?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe it was written by a certain perſon called Matthew.

p.hi: What account do we receive of that Perſon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He is called by ſeveral Names: One (S. Mark, chap. 2.14.) calls him Levi the Son of Alpheus; another (S. Luke, chap. 5.27.) calls him only Levi; but he calls himſelf Matthew the Publican, (Matth. 9.9.)

p.hi: How came he concerned in writing this Goſpel?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He was called by Chriſt from the Office
of a Publican, to be one of his Twelve Apoſtles, and inſpired by the Holy Ghoſt to write this Goſpel.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Which of the Four Living Creatures mentioned in Ezekiel's Viſion, repreſented S. Matthew?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That which had the Face of a man; becauſe he begins with our Saviour's Genealogy.

p.hi: How doth he derive our Saviour's Pedigree?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
More generally,
Chap. 1 from Abraham and David.

p.hi: Why are theſe two Perſons eſpecially mentioned?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To aſſure us that Chriſt came not only from the Race of the Jews, of whom Abraham was the Great Father; but likewiſe (according to the Propheſie, Gen. 49.10.) from the Tribe of Judah; of which David was, and alſo from the Princely Line of that Tribe.

p.hi: How is our Saviour's Pedigree derived more particularly?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: From Abraham and David, by ſucceſſion all along till it terminated in Joſeph.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who was that Joſeph?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Perſon (then Eſpouſed) afterward Married to Mary our Saviour's Mother.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: But was Joſeph, Chriſt's Father?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Reputedly, he was ſo among the Jews: but he had no Natural Father, being conceived by the Operation of the Holy Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Was Joſeph married to Mary before Chriſt was born?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was only Eſpouſed, according to the Cuſtom of the Jews, a good while after Chriſt's Conception; and Married a little before Chriſt was born, when ſhe was great with Child of him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Was Mary's being with Child no diſcontent to Joſeph?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; ſo great an one, that he reſolved to put her away (but privately, becauſe ſhe ſhould not be expoſed to ſhame) till in a Dream he was ſatisfied by an Angel of God to the contrary.

p.hi: What was alledged by the Angel for his ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That the Child within her was conceived of the Holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Why was his Conception and Birth ordered in this manner?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To fulfil Iſaiah's Propheſie, That a Virgin ſhould conceive and bear a Son.

p.hi: What Name was given to this Child when he was born?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Name (by the Angel's appointment) was called JESUS, becauſe he ſhould ſave his People from their ſins.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Publick Notice doth this Evangeliſt give of JESUS's Birth being declared to other Nations?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 2 He tells us of Wiſe men who came from the Eaſt to enquire after him, by the ſtrange Appearance of a New Star.

p.hi: Ʋnder what Notion did they enquire for him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: As one that was born King of the Jews.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Herod (who then Reigned over Judea) take this Enquiry?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It put him into a great affright; whereupon he ſent for the Chief Prieſts and Elders (ſuppoſing this was the MESSIAS) demanding of them, Where CHRIST ſhould be born?

p.hi: What Anſwer did they give him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Anſwer according to the former Propheſie of Micah, That he ſhould be born in Bethlehem.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What courſe did Herod take for further ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He ſent the Wiſe Men to Bethlehem, to find out the Child, under pretence of his own coming afterwards to worſhip him.

p.hi: How were thoſe Wiſe Men guided thither?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſame Star was their Conductor, till they came to the very place where the Child lay, and then it ſtood ſtill.

p.hi: Did they find'him as they were directed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They found Him and His Mother with him.

p.hi: How did they carry themſelves towards him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Firſt they worſhipped him, and then they preſented him with an Offering of Gold, Frar kincenſe and Myrrhe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did thoſe Wiſe-men return to Herod, as he deſired?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for being warned of God in a Dream, they departed into their own Countrey another way.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Herod take this Affront?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He reſolved to deſtroy this Child; and to be ſure of it, he ſlew all the Children in Bethlehem, and the Coaſts thereof, from two years old and under.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How then was this Babe ſecured?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Angel had commanded his (reputed) Father Joſeph to convey him into Egypt, till notice was given for his Return; which was upon Herod's Death: and then he was brought back to Nazareth a City of Galilee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did not John Baptiſt appear in the World about that time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes:
Chap. 3 He Preached in the Wilderneſs of Judea the Doctrine of Repentance, and Baptized thoſe that came unto him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What kind of Man was John?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A man of a very Auſtere Life; for his Rayment was of Camels Hair, with a Leathern Girdle about his Loyns; and his Meat was Locuſts and wild Honey.

p.hi: By whom was Chriſt Baptized?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By John Baptiſt in Jordan.

p.hi: Was any Signal Teſtimony given of him at his Baptiſm?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The greateſt that ever was; for the Heavens were opened, the Spirit of God deſcended upon him like a Dove, and God himſelf by open voice acknowledged him to be his Well-beloved Son.

p.hi: What happened unto Chriſt after his Baptiſm?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
His Temptation in the Wilderneſs by the Devil,
Chap. 4 for forty days, during which time he did eat nothing; but at the end of them was an hungred.

p.hi: How many Temptations did he meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Three

p.hi: Which was the firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Devil taking advantage of Chriſts Hunger, Tempted him to turn Stones into Bread.

p.hi: What was the Second?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Temptation to throw himſelf from a Pinacle of the Temple, to ſhew his Divinity.

p.hi: What was the Third?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Temptation to fall down and worſhip Satan, upon promiſe to have all the Kingdoms of the Earth, and the Glory of them given unto him.

p.hi: How were all theſe Temptations repelled?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By ſeveral Places of Scripture fitted to each of them.

p.hi: What was the Iſſue of all?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Devil left him, and Angels came and Miniſtred unto him.

p.hi: Whither did our Saviour then remove?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He departed into Galilee, and dwelt in Capernaum.

p.hi: Who were the firſt that Chriſt called to be his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two Brothers, Andrew and Peter.

p.hi: Who were the next?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two other Brothers, James and John the Sons of Zebedee.

p.hi: Where did he find them all?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He found them following their Employment (as Fiſhers) by the Sea of Galilee.

p.hi: Did not the People then begin to take notice of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes. His Fame was ſpred abroad by his Preaching, and Healing all manner of Diſeaſes.

p.hi: What ſignal Teſtimony did he give of his excellent Preaching?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 5 It was manifeſt by his Sermon on the Mount.

p.hi: Whereof doth that Sermon principally conſiſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It conſiſts of Three Parts: of which I ſhall give you account in order.

p.hi: What is the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Bleſſing pronounced to the Poor in Spirit, the Mourners, the Meek, thoſe that Hunger and Thirſt after Righteouſneſs, the Merciful, the Pure in Heart, the Peace-makers, and the Sufferers for Righteouſneſs ſake.

p.hi: What is the Second Part of this Sermon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Confutation of ſeveral Erroneous Opinions of the Jewiſh Doctors, as to ſundry parts of God's Law, touching Murder, v. 21. Adultery, v. 28. Divorcements, v. 31. Falſe Swearing, v. 34. and Repaying of Injuries,
to the End of the Chapter

p.hi: What is the Third Part of this Sermon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chap. 6 A Direction for the Performance of ſeveral Duties; as Almeſ-giving, v. 1. Prayer, v. 5. (Chriſt there ſetting down his moſt Excellent Form, as a Pattern for Prayer;) Faſting, v. 16. Dependance on God's Providence, v. 25, to the End of the Chapter; and ſeveral other excellent things in the Seventh Chapter.
Chap. 7

p.hi: How was this Sermon approved?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So well, that he was extolled beyond the Scribes and Phariſees.

p.hi: What happened after this Sermon was ended?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several Miracles done by Chriſt, to be diſcourſed of in Order.

p.hi: Which was the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 8 The Curing of a Leprous man of his Diſeaſe.

p.hi: Which was the Next?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Healing the Centurion's Servant, who was ſick of a Palſie, upon his Maſter's coming and beſeeching Chriſt to do it.

p.hi: Which was the Third?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Curing S. Peter's Wives Mother, who lay ſick of a Fever, by the Touch of his hand; and ſeveral others poſſeſſed with Devils.

p.hi: What other Miracle is declared in this Chapter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Calming the Sea, when his Diſciples were in danger to be drowned, and prayed
for his aſſiſtance, which he gave them; aſſwaging the Tempeſt with a Word of his Mouth.

p.hi: What Effect had this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Diſciples marvelled at it, wondring who he was to whom the Wind and the Sea gave ſuch ready Obedience.

p.hi: What Miracle doth this Evangeliſt next record?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Caſting out Devils out of Two men Poſſeſſed, in the Countrey of the Gergeſenes.

p.hi: What became of thoſe Devils?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At their Requeſt, Chriſt ſuffered them to enter into an Herd of Swine feeding thereabouts, who preſently ran down a ſteep place into the Lake, and periſhed in the Waters.

p.hi: How was this Miracle entertained by the People of that Countrey?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They that kept the Swine fled, telling in their City what was done, and they all came to ſee Jeſus, and deſired that he would depart from them.

p.hi: Whither did he go from thence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He went by Ship to his own City.

p.hi: What Miracle did he work there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He healed a man ſick of the Palſie,
Chap. 9 brought to him upon a Bed.

p.hi: What happened upon this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Scribes hearing him ſay to the man, Thy Sins are forgiven thee, and thinking he Blaſphemed, to convince them of their Error, he bad him take up his Bed and walk.

p.hi: What was the next thing remarkable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt's calling Matthew a Publican from the receipt of Cuſtom, to follow him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Matthew entertain him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a great Feaſt in his own Houſe where many Publicans and Sinners were gathered together.

p.hi: Was there no Exception taken at the thing?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes. The Phariſees quarrelled wit • his Diſciples about it.

p.hi: What Anſwer did Chriſt make to them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He declared the Reaſonableneſs o • what he dad done, by the End of his Comin •
into the world, which was, not to call th • Righteous, but Sinners to Repentance.

p.hi: What other Cavil had the Phariſees againſt him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That He and his Diſciples did not faſ •
as their Diſciples and John Baptiſt's Diſc •
ples did.

p.hi: How did Chriſt excuſe himſelf and h •• Diſciples in this Point?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By an Alluſion to the Attendants u • on a Marriage, who uſed not to mourn whi •• the Bridegroom was with them.

p.hi: What might the meaning hereof be?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That he being the True Bridegroon his Diſciples muſt rejoyce while he con •
nued with them upon Earth; but when 〈◊〉 ſhould be taken away by Death, then th •• muſt be exerciſed with Faſting, and oth •• Duties of Mortification.

p.hi: How elſe was his Excuſe made?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By New Pieces of Cloth not to be put upon Old Garments, nor New Wine into Old Bottles.

p.hi: Whither was Chriſt called from this Feaſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Ruler of the Synagogue (called Jairus) having a Daughter very ſick, deſired him to come and heal her.

p.hi: Did any thing of Note happen in the way as he went to do this Cure?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for a Poor Woman having been troubled with an Iſſue of Blood Twelve years, came behind him, and touched his Garment, whereby ſhe was made whole.

p.hi: In what condition was the Rulers Daughter when Chriſt came to her?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The People about her apprehended her to be dead.

p.hi: Was ſhe recovered from her Sickneſs or not?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She was recovered; for Chriſt took her by the Hand, and ſhe was well.

p.hi: What other Cures did he work?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He gave ſight to Two Blind men, by
• ouching their Eyes; and Speech to one that was Dumb.

p.hi: What happened after theſe laſt Miraples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chriſt from among his Diſciples,
Chap. 10 choſe • ut Twelve Apoſtles, whom he ſent forth • ot only to Preach the Goſpel, but to caſt
• ut unclean Spirits, and to heal all manner of Diſeaſes.

p.hi: What were the Names of thoſe Twelve Apoſtles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Peter, Andrew, James the Son of Zebedce, John his Brother, Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, Matthew, James the Son of Alpheus, Lebbeus (called Thaddeus,) Simon the Canaanite, and Judas (afterwards) the Traytor.

p.hi: With what Charge did Chriſt ſend forth theſe Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Not to go among the Gentiles, but to the loſt ſheep of the Houſe of Iſrael,

p.hi: What Advice did he give them upon their going forth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He taught them in what Meanneſ •
they ſhould go, to teſtifie their Humility what Troubles they ſhould endure, to encourage their Patience; and promiſed then Bleſſings, to ſtrengthen their Faith.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Was any Notice of theſe things give to John Baptiſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
His Diſciples gave him an Account o • them;
Chap. 11 whereupon they deſired to know he was indeed the True Meſſias?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did John do to ſatisfie them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He ſent Two of them to Chriſt wit • this very Queſtion.

p.hi: What Anſwer did they receive?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chriſt bade them inform John of th •
Miracles he wrought; that the Blind ſa ••
the Deaf heard, the Dumb ſpake, the L •
pers were cleanſed, the Lame walked, t ••
Dead were raiſed, and the Poor had the G •
ſpel Preached unto them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did our Saviour then tell his Followers concerning John?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By ſeveral Similitudes he ſets forth the Excellency of John; but withal, that John came far ſhort of him.

p.hi: Of what did he then begin to diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He upbraided the City (eſpecially Capernaum) wherein his mighty Works had been wrought.

p.hi: How happened the next Quarrel betwixt Chriſt and the Phariſees?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
About his Diſciples plucking Ears of Corn as they went through the Field,
Chap. 12 for the ſatisfying their Hunger, it being on the Sabbath Day.

p.hi: How did our Saviour vindicate his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Example of David, taking the Shew-Bread (in time of neceſſity) for Himſelf and his Followers; and the Prieſts killing Sacrifices in the Temple on that Day; Averring himſelf to be greater than the Temple, and Lord of the Sabbath.

p.hi: What Miracle followed after this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Healing a man poſſeſſed with a Devil who was both Blind and Dumb.

p.hi: How did the Phariſees except againſt this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They alledged that Chriſt did caſt out Devils through the Prince of the Devils.

p.hi: How did Chriſt convince them to the contrary?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By an Argument that every Houſe
and Kingdom divided could not ſubſiſt; and therefore Satan divided againſt himſelf, could not ſtand.

p.hi: Did not Chriſt from hence take occaſion for ſome further Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He did; and it was to acquaint them with the Sin (i.e. the Blaſphemy) againſt the Holy Ghoſt, which was unpardonable; and to give them a Caution againſt all idle and uncharitable words.

p.hi: What did the Phariſees then require of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Sign from Heaven.

p.hi: Did he anſwer their Deſire?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He did; but it was with a Reproof, giving them the Signs of Jonah and the Queen of the South.

p.hi: How lay the Reproof under theſe things?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That whereas the Ninevites repented at Jonah's Preaching, and the Queen of the South came from far to hear Solomon's Wiſdom; yet they would not be wrought upon by him, who was Greater than either Jonah or Solomon.

p.hi: What further Manifeſtations did Chriſt make of himſelf to the People.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By ſeveral Parables; Of the Sower and his Seed;
Chap. 13 Of the Tares and Good Wheat; by reſembling the Kingdom of Heaven to a Grain of Muſtard-Seed; to Treaſure hid in a Field; to a Net which drew Fiſhes of all ſorts out of the Sea.

p.hi: How did theſe Parables and his other Inſtructions take?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The People wondred at his Wiſdom, but were offended at him for the Meanneſs of his Birth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Opinion had Herod of Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Herod hearing of his Fame,
Chap. 14 ſaid it was John the Baptiſt (whom he had ſlain) riſen from the dead.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ʋpon what occaſion did Herod ſlay John Baptiſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Herod long reproved by John for keeping Herodias, his Brother's Wife, ſhut him up in priſon; and at her Daughters Dancing to pleaſe him, ſwore to give her what ſhe requeſted; whereupon, ſhe deſiring John Baptiſt's Head, an Executioner was employed to behead him in the Priſon, and the Head was delivered to her in a Charger.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Kindneſs did John's Diſciples ſhew to their dead Maſter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They buried his Body, and came to acquaint Jeſus with what had happened.

p.hi: How did Jeſus then diſpoſe of himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He removed from the place where he was into a Deſart place; whither the Multitude followed him, and there he healed their ſick.

p.hi: What Miracle did he work there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He fed five Thouſand Men beſide Women and Children, with Five Loaves and Two Fiſhes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What remainder of Fragments was there to perfect the Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
After they were all filled, there were
taken up Twelve Baskets full of Fragments.

p.hi: Whither did Chriſt go after this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He went into a Mountain to pray; and ſent his Diſciples in a Ship towards the other ſide of the Water.

p.hi: What kind of Paſſage had they?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Storm aroſe, ſo that the Ship was toſſed with Waves; and Chriſt appeared unto them walking on the Sea, at which ſight they were much affrighted.

p.hi: What Comfort did they receive under this fright?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt comforted them with telling them who he was,

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How would Peter be ſatisfied in the truth of that Relation?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He deſired that Chriſt would command him to come unto him; and he attempting to do ſo, was in danger of his Life, but that Chriſt took hold of him to ſave him; and then the Storm ceaſed.

p.hi: Where did they Land after the Storm was over?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In the Land of Geneſaret; and there Chriſt healed ſeveral ſick perſons with the Touch of his Garment.

p.hi: Had the Phariſees any more Accuſations againſt Chriſt's Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They accuſed them for eating Meat with unwaſhen Hands.
Chap. 15

p.hi: How did Chriſt rebuke this Challenge?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By telling them they inſiſted only upon a Tradition, and ſo out of the Propheſie
of Iſaiah, charging them with Hypocriſie.

p.hi: Was not this further illuſtrated?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; By ſhewing them that not the things which go into, but thoſe which come out of a man, defile him; which Parable he expounded to his Diſciples.

p.hi: To what Place did Chriſt then go?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To the Coaſts of Tyre and Sidon.

p.hi: What Object of Charity did he there meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Canaanitiſh Woman cried to him for help on behalf of her Daughter, who was grievouſly vexed with a Devil.

p.hi: Did Chriſt heal her?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: After ſeveral Diſcourſes paſſed between them, the Woman ſtill continuing importunate; the Daughter was healed, and the Mothers Faith confirmed.

p.hi: Whither went Jeſus next?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To a Mountain nigh the Sea of Galilee.

p.hi: What Remarkable things did he do there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He healed ſeveral Diſtempered perſons, and fed Four Thouſand Men, beſides Women and Children, with Seven Loaves, and a few little Fiſhes.

p.hi: What remained when the People had eaten?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Seven Baskets full of Fragments were taken up.

p.hi: What Entertainment did Chriſt there meet with from his Oppoſers?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Scribes and Phariſees tempted
Chap. 16
him for a Sign from Heaven, which he refuſed; leaving them to the Sign of the Prophet Jonas, and taxing them with Hypocriſie.

p.hi: How did he hence take occaſion to inſtruct his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He cautioned them againſt the Doctrine of the Phariſees and Sadduces (under the Notion of Leaven.)

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What happened upon Chriſt's coming into the Coaſts of Ceſarea-Philippi.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Asking his Diſciples what men thought of him; they told him, He was taken for John Baptiſt, or Elias, or Jeremias, or one of the Prophets; but asking their thoughts of him, Peter acknowledgeth him to be the Chriſt, the Son of the Living God.

p.hi: How did Chriſt take this Confeſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So well, that he pronounced Peter Bleſſed; gave him the Name of Peter, and diſpoſed the Keys of the Kingdom of Heaven to him (though not without the reſt) promiſing, that the Gates (i. e. the Power) of Hell ſhould not prevail againſt his Church.

p.hi: What further Diſcourſe had Chriſt with his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He declared unto them the Sufferings he was to undergo, his Death and Reſurrection; rebuking S. Peter for contradicting what he ſuffered; and taught his Diſciples the hard Duties of Self-denial, Suffering Afflictions, and Renouncing the World.

p.hi: By what eſpecial Argument did he urge theſe Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Excellency of the Soul above all that the World can afford.

p.hi: What followed after this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chriſt's Transfiguration,
Chap. 17 about ſix days after, before Peter, James and John.

p.hi: What were the Circumſtances attending that Transfiguration?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Shining of his Face, the Whiteneſs of his Raiment, and the appearing of Moſes and Elias unto him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did S. Peter adviſe at this time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That Three Tabernacles might be built, one for Chriſt, a ſecond for Moſes, and a third for Elias.

p.hi: Did thoſe two continue long with Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for a bright Cloud overſhadowed them, and they were ſeen no more.

p.hi: Was there any particular Declaration then given of Chriſt's Divinity?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There was a Voice heard out of the Cloud to own Chriſt as God's Beloved Son.

p.hi: What Miracles did Chriſt do after his Transfiguration?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The firſt was Healing a man Lunatick; which his Diſciples not being able to do, He did it Himſelf.

p.hi: What Diſcourſe did he make upon this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Diſcourſe (as before) of his Sufferings.

p.hi: Whither did he go then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Capernaum?

p.hi: What Miracle was wrought there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Tribute-gatherers coming, he ordered S. Peter to go to the Sea, and take the firſt Fiſh that came up, in whoſe Mouth was found a Piece of Money, which paid for them both.

p.hi: What Leſſons did our Saviour then teach his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Leſſons of Humility and Innocency,
Chap. 18 by becoming as Little Children; of Inoffenſiveneſs, and Forgiving one another; urging this laſt by a Parable of a Maſter forgiving his Servant a Great Debt at his Requeſt, which Servant would not forgive his Fellow-Servant a Small Debt, when he was deſired to do it; whereupon the Firſt Servant was puniſhed by being caſt into Priſon.

p.hi: What was the next Diſcourſe of Note?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Concerning Divorces;
Chap. 19 upon a Queſtion propounded by the Phariſees about the Lawfulneſs of putting away Wives, permitted under the Law.

p.hi: How did Chriſt reſolve the Queſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He told them the Original Inſtitution of Marriage, which made it not diſſolvable; and that the Allowance of Moſes was only for the hardneſs of the Peoples Hearts; concluding there could be no Divorce but in caſe of Adultery.

p.hi: What followed upon this;

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Young Children were preſented unto him, on whom he laid his hands, and Bleffſed them.

p.hi: What Viſiters had he then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One moſt remarkable; A young man coming to enquire what he ſhould do to have Eternal Life.

p.hi: What Direction did Chriſt give him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Direction to keep the Commandments, which he named unto him.

p.hi: Did the man obſerve this Direction?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He profeſſed to have done it from his very youth.

p.hi: What trial did Chriſt make of the truth of his Profeſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He gave him a particular Charge of ſelling his Eſtate, and giving it to the poor, with a Promiſe of Treaſure in Heaven.

p.hi: Was this Charge well received?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; the man went away ſorrowful, having great Poſſeſſions, which he was loth to part with.

p.hi: What did our Saviour draw from hence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Difficulty of a Rich man's being ſaved?

p.hi: What Queſtion did this occaſion from the Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Peter asked what Reward himſelf and the reſt of them ſhould have, who had forſaken all to follow him.

p.hi: What Anſwer did Chriſt give to this Qneſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He promiſed them a Reward both in this and in another World.

p.hi: Was there no Parable propounded upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
There was the Parable of Reſembing
Chap. 20
the Kingdom of Heaven to a Houſholder, hiring Labourers into his Vineyard, at ſeveral hours of the day, and then paying each man his Penny according to agreement.

p.hi: Whither was our Saviour's next Journey?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Jeruſalem; where in the way he again admoniſhed his Diſciples of the Sufferings which ſhould befal him to his Death, and the Certainty of his Reſurrection the Third day.

p.hi: Whom did he meet with in the way?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Mother of Zebedees Children coming to requeſt him that her two Sons might ſit on his Right and Left hands in his Kingdom.

p.hi: How did he anſwer her?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That they ſhould ſuffer with him; but thoſe Places muſt be diſpoſed of according to his Father's Deſignation.

p.hi: Did not this vex the other Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; They were angry at the Two Brethren for it.

p.hi: How did Chriſt remove that Anger?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By teaching them all to be lowly minded, after his own example.

p.hi: What particular Miracle was wrought this time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two Blind men ſitting by the way ſide (upon their ſupplicating him) ha • their Eye-ſight reſtored unto them.

p.hi: What elſe happened?
p.label: Chap. 21

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
At Bethpage near Jeruſalem, he ſen • by a particular Token for a Colt, on which
he rode into Jeruſalem, to fulfil a Propheſie • f the Old Teſtament.

p.hi:
How was he entertained by the Com
• any?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Multitude ſpread their Garments, and ſtrewed Branches in the way, ſaluted
• im with loud proclamations of Hoſannahs at his coming into the City.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
What was his firſt Work in Jeruſa
• em?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An entring into the Temple, and caſting out the Buyers and Sellers in it, and there healing the Blind and the Lame.

p.hi: How did the Chief Prieſts and Scribes take the Acclamations of joy which the People made?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With ſo much indignation that they complained of them.

p.hi: How was the Complaint ſilenced?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Chriſt's alledging a place of Scripture (Pſal. 8.2.) in the Peoples vindication.

p.hi: Whither went Chriſt from thence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He went to lodge in Bethany.

p.hi: What Miracle did he work there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The next morning he curſed a fruitleſs Fig-Tree, which Curſe took effect; for it preſently withered away.

p.hi: What Diſputes happened about that that Time?
Several.
Which was the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Diſpute with the Chief Prieſts and Elders concerning John Baptist's Baptiſm
and Preaching, whether it was from He •
ven or not, which Queſtion Chriſt put unt • them, when they enquired into his Auth •
rity.

p.hi: What Anſwer did they give him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They durſt not delcare their Opinio •
concerning John, and he would not give the • an account of his Authority.

p.hi: What was the Reſult of this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It gave occaſion for Two Parables one of Two Sons, the firſt pretending to d • his Fathers will, and not doing it; the other refuſing to do it at firſt, but doing it after wards.

p.hi:
What was the meaning of this Par •
ble?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chriſt compares the Jews with the ••
pretence to Religion of the firſt Son; th • Publicans and Sinners to the ſecond; ſhewing thereby, that theſe entred into th • Kingdom of Heaven ſooner than the Jews.

p.hi: What was the next Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Of an Houſholder, who having pla •
ted a Vineyard, ſent his ſervants to receiv • the Fruits, ſome of which the Husbandme •
beat, and killed others; at laſt ſending h ••
Son among them, they ſlew him, to mak • the Inheritance their own.

p.hi:
What was the meaning of this Par •
ble?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Our Saviour doth hereby repreſen • the hard uſage which the Prophets had me • with from the Jews; and likewiſe ſignifie • what he expected at their hands; whereupon
would follow the taking Gods Ordi
• ances from them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
How did this Parable reliſh with the
• ews?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They perceived he had ſpoken of
• hem, and would have laid hands upon him, • ut durſt not for fear of the people.

p.hi: What other Parable did he put • orth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
One to the ſame purpoſe, of a King,
Chap, 22
• ho making a Marriage for his Son, invited • everal Gueſts, who refuſing to come, and •• ſing his Servants ill, were deſtroyed; and 〈◊〉
Command given to call in as many as the • ervants could find, from the High-ways and Hedges.

p.hi: What was the intent of this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
It was to ſhew the Rejection of the
• ews, and the Calling of the Gentiles.

p.hi: What was the Second Diſpute?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: How did he puzzle them by his Anſwer?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He appointed the Payment, ſhewing was Caeſar's Due, by having Caeſar's I
• age and Superſcription upon it; at • hich Anſwer they wondred, and left • im.

p.hi: What was the Third Diſpute?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Diſpute about the Reſurrection • ith the Sadduces, which they denied.

p.hi:
How did they frame their Argument •
gainſt it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By an Inſtance out of the Law whi •• commanded a Brother to take the ſurvivi •• Widow of his Brother to Wife, for raiſi •• up Seed; and thereupon alledging that ſev •• Brethren in order had taken one Woman they asked to which of thoſe Seven ſhe ſhou • belong at the Reſurrection.

p.hi: How did Chriſt refute this Argument?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By declaring their Miſtake abo •• Marriages in the other World; and alledgin • a Paſſage out of Exodus, where God ca •• himſelf the God of Abraham, Iſaac an •
Jacob, who were all dead, but muſt riſ •
again.

p.hi: How was this Anſwer taken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The whole Multitude did might •
applaud Chriſt for it.

p.hi: What was the Fourth Diſpute?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Phariſees (deſirous to ſilen ••
him) employed one to ask what was the gre •• Commandment.

p.hi: How did Chriſt anſwer this Queſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He reſolved the whole Law into T ••
Precepts; the Loving God, as the Firſt, an • the Loving our Neighbour, as the Second.

p.hi: What followed after this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Queſtion which Chriſt asked the concerning the Meſſiah's being the Son •• David; and proving him to be ſo, whe • they could not anſwer it.

p.hi: What did he take occaſion thence to t ••• his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He gave them order to attend to the good Doctrine of the Scribes and Phariſees,
Chap. 23 but to beware of their Ambition, their Hypocriſie and Cruelty in killing the Prophets of God; bewailing the Conditon of Jeruſalem upon that account.

p.hi: What ground of Diſcourſe did his Diſciples give him at his going from the Temple?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Upon their ſhewing him thoſe goodly Buildings,
Chap. 24 he Propheſied the Deſtruction of the Temple, and thence proceeded to foretel the utter Deſolation of Jeruſalem, and the End of the World.

p.hi: What Duty did he urge thereupon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Duty of Watchfulneſs, for fear • eſt that time ſhould ſurprize them (and •• us) unawares; promiſing a Bleſſing to thoſe • hat do Watch, and denouncing a Judgment • gainſt thoſe that are negligent.

p.hi: Did that Head of Diſcourſe end ſo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for Chriſt thereupon uttered Two Parables.

p.hi: Which was the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Parable of Ten Virgins going to
• eet the Bridegroom, Five wiſe,
Chap. 25 and Five • ooliſh; the wiſe took Oil with their Lamps, • he fooliſh did not; who afterwards wanting, • ould have borrowed of the wiſe; but they • efuſed to lend; whereupon going forth to
• uy, the Bridegroom came in the mean while, and thoſe who were ready, went to • he Marriage, but the reſt were ſhut out.

p.hi: What doth this Parable teach?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The neceſſity of having Grace at all times ready, that it may not be to ſeek when it is to be uſed; leſt at Chriſt's coming we be found unfit to be received by him.

p.hi: Which was the Second Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A man Travelling abroad, gave ſeveral Talents to ſeveral Servants (ſome more, ſome leſs) wherewith they ſhould Trade for Advantage; Two doing ſo, were rewarded; One neglecting, was puniſhed, and his Talent given to him that had the moſt.

p.hi: What is the Deſign of this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It teacheth us, That all the Gifts o • God are to be well Husbanded; and then he will both Encreaſe and Reward them: but if we be careleſs, and bury them in ſilence, he will take them from us, and puniſh u • too.

p.hi: What follows after theſe Parables?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Deſcription of the General Judgment, with the Eternal Bleſſing upon th • Righteous for their Works of Charity; with the Everlasting Curſe upon the wicked fo • their Ʋncharitableneſs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Was there any Conſpiracy made by th •
Jews againſt Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They laid a Deſign to apprehend an •
kill him.

p.hi: What happened before they took him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 26 A Woman in Bethany anointed him with very precious Ointment, whoſe goo • work he commended, though his Diſciple ſpake againſt it.

p.hi: By whom was Chriſt betrayed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Judas Iſcariot, one of his Diſciples, who covenanted with the Chief Prieſts to do it for Thirty Pieces of Silver.

p.hi: What opportunity was offered for the effecting it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Jeſus according to his cuſtom, keeping the Paſsover, did diſcover Judas his Treachery unto him; and there the Occaſion was taken.

p.hi: What did Jeſus at the end of the Paſs-over-Supper?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He inſtituted his own Supper in Bread and Wine; and after the ſinging an Hymn, went unto the Mount of Olives.

p.hi: What did he there declare unto his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Their Fear of ſuffering, which would be ſeen in forſaking him that night.

p.hi: How was this taken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Peter pretended a great deal of Courage, that though All ſhould forſake Chriſt, He would not; nay he would rather die with him than deny him: and the reſt aſſerted the ſame.

p.hi: Whither did Chriſt then betake himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Gethſemane; where chuſing out Peter, James, and John to watch with him, he went and PRAYED THREE TIMES for the removal of his Bitter Cup.

p.hi: Did the Diſciples Watch according to his bidding?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
No. He found them aſleep each time,
at his return to them (for he had withdrawn himſelf a little way from them.)

p.hi: What followed ſhortly after theſe Prayers?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The coming of Judas, and a Multitude with him, having ſwords and ſtaves for their own defence.

p.hi: What fign was given to know the perſon betrayed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Judas had promiſed to come to him with a Kiſs, whereupon Chriſt was immediately apprehended.

p.hi: Did his Diſciples do nothing in order to his Reſcue?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One of them (S. Peter) cut off a Servant's right ear who belonged to the high Prieſt; whereupon Chriſt commanded the Sword to be ſheathed again.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither was Jeſus then carried?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To the Palace of Caiaphas the High Prieſt, where the Scribes and Phariſees were aſſembled.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What became of Peter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He followed afar off, and ſate with the Servants to ſee the iſſue of the Buſineſs.

p.hi: How was Chriſt proceeded againſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By endeavouring to ſuborn Falſe witneſſes againſt him, to whoſe Teſtimony he would anſwer nothing.

p.hi: What did they do at length to condemn him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The High Prieſt adjuring him to declare if he were the Chriſt, he confeſſed it; which Confeſſion they alledging to be Blaſphemy,
ſtraightway he was condemned to Death.

p.hi: How did the Multitude then uſe him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſpat in his face, buffetted him, and ſmote him with their hands.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What became of Peter all this while?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He being charged as one of Chriſt's Diſciples, denied it three times, with Oaths and Curſes; after which (according to his Maſter's Propheſie) the Cock crowed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Peter take this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Remembring the words of Chriſt, he went out and wept bitterly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To whom was Chriſt carried from Caiaphas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Jews deſigning his Death,
Chap. 27 delivered him over to Pilate.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Judas ſpeed after the betraying his Maſter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt being condemned, Judas his guilty Conſcience accuſed him; whereupon, he confeſſed his Sin, brought again the Money he had received, and hanged himſelf.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Chriſt behave himſelf before Pilate?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He would not Anſwer to the things alledged againſt him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did not Pilate uſe to ſhew the Jews ſome particular Favour at the Paſsover-time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes. He uſed to releaſe ſuch a Priſoner as they ſhould chuſe.

p.hi: Why then was not Chriſt releaſed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe the People choſe Barabbas before him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What warning had Pilate given him not to be concerned in Chriſt's Death?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Wife ſent him a Caution to the Judgment-Seat where he ſate, that he ſhould not meddle with him; becauſe ſhe had ſuffered many things in a Dream.

p.hi: How did he declare his Innocency when Chriſt was to ſuffer?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He called for a Baſon of Water, in which he waſhed his hands; aſſerting himſelf innocent of his Blood.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did the Jews take it upon themſelves?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a dreadful Imprecation: His Blood be on us and on our Children.

p.hi: How then did they proceed againſt Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was ſcourged, ſtripped of his Robes, cloathed in Scarlet, crowned with a Crown of Thorns, and carried to Golgotha, with his Croſs born before him.

p.hi: What did they to him there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They gave him Vinegar mingled with Drink, and Crucified him between Two Thieves.

p.hi: What Miracles happened at his Crucifixion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A General Darkneſs over the Earth for three hours, the Vail of the Temple rent, the Earth quaking, the Rock ſplit in pieces, the Graves opening, and many Bodies of the Saints ariſing.

p.hi: How did this work upon the Centurion then in Command?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It extorted from him and thoſe preſent, a Confeſſion that Chriſt was the Son of God.

p.hi: Did no one beg his dead Body?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; Joſeph of Arimathea, one of Chriſt's Diſciples privately, begg'd it of Pilate.

p.hi: How did he diſpoſe of it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wrapping it in clean Linnen, he laid it in his own new Tomb hewen out of a Rock, and rolled a great ſtone to the door of the Sepulchre.

p.hi: What care did the Scribes and Phariſees take that he ſhould not riſe again?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They deſired of Pilate a Watch about the Sepulchre, leſt his Diſciples ſhould come by night and ſteal him away.

p.hi: When, and in what manner did Chriſt riſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Early on the Firſt day of the Week,
Chap. 28 with a great Earthquake: The Angel of the Lord rolling away the ſtone from the Sepulchre, and ſitting upon it.

p.hi: How was this Reſurrection made known?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Angel, to thoſe women who came to the Sepulchre, and found not his Body.

p.hi: What Influence had the Angel's Relation upon thoſe Women?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They departed from the Sepulchre with fear and great joy, to carry theſe Tidings to his Diſciples.

p.hi: Did not Chriſt himſelf appear to them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes; He appeared in the way, and
gave them order to appoint his Diſciples to meet him in Galilee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How was this diſcovered in Jeruſalem?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some of the Watch came, and told the Chief Prieſts what was done.

p.hi: How did the Chief Prieſts endeavour to conceal the truth of it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Bribing the Souldiers to report that his Diſciples came in the night to ſteal him away; which Report the Jews ſtill believe.

p.hi: Did Chriſt meet his Diſciples according to his Appointment?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; and there diſcourſed with them of his Almighty Power.

p.hi: What particular Command did he give them at that time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That they ſhould go abroad Teaching and Baptizing in the Name of the Father, Son, and Holy Ghoſt; Inſtructing men to be obedient unto his Commands, and then Comforted them with a Promiſe of his Preſence to the End of the World.

div.trailer: The End of S. MATTHEW.

div.head: S. MARK.

p.hi: HOw doth the Goſpel of S. MARK begin?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 1 With an Account of John's Preaching in the Wilderneſs, and Propheſying of our Saviour Chriſt; whereupon he is ſignified by Ezekiel's Lion.

p.hi: What doth this Goſpel contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is almoſt an Abridgment of the former, with ſome few Additions, (ſix in Number) now only neceſſary to be taken notice of.

p.hi: What is the firſt conſiderable Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 6 The Account of John Baptiſt's being ſlain by Herod; where ſeveral Circumſtances are mentioned, which the other Evangeliſts take no notice of.

p.hi: What be thoſe Circumſtances;

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The great Opinion which Herod had of John, as a juſt man and an holy: The time when his Death happened, when Herod upon his Birth-Day made a Feaſt to the great perſons of his Kingdom; and the particular Direction Herodias gave her Daughter of asking John Baptiſt's Head.

p.hi: What is the Second Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Miracle which Chriſt 〈…〉 upon a man that was Deaf, and 〈…〉
••
pediment in his Speech, by putting his 〈…〉
into the man's Ears, ſpitting and touching his Tongue.

p.hi: What is the Third Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 8 The Cure of one at Bethſaida who was Blind.

p.hi: How was he cured?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt ſpat upon his Eyes, whereupon he ſaw men as Trees, walking; and putting his Hands upon them again, the ſight was perfectly reſtored.

p.hi: What Charge did Chriſt then give him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Neither to go into the Town, nor to tell it in the Town.

p.hi: What is the Fourth Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 9 Our Saviour's Rebuke to his Apoſtle John, upon forbidding a man to caſt out Devils in Chriſt's Name, becauſe he was not of their Company: Aſſuring him that whoſoever was not againſt Chriſt was on his part.

p.hi: What is the Fifth Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 12 A more particular Account of the Scribe who enquired of Chriſt, which was the Firſt and Great Commandment.

p.hi: What is there conſiderable in this Evangeliſt's Relation of the Story?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Approbation which the Scribe gave to our Saviour's Anſwer; acknowledging for a Truth the Ʋnity of the Godhead; that the Love of God and our Neighbour was beyond all Offerings and Sacrifices: whereupon Chriſt for his diſcreet Reply, took a Love to him, and declared that he was not far from the Kingdom of God.

p.hi: What is the Sixth Addition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 16 It hath Relation to what followed upon our Saviour's Reſurrection; ſomething more Particular, ſomething more General.

p.hi: What is the Particular Matter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Comfort eſpecially ſent to Peter by Name (who had before denied him) concerning his Reſurrection; and his firſt appearance to Mary Magdalen, a great Sinner.

p.hi: What are the General Things?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Diſciples not believing their Maſter's Reſurrection when it was told them by Mary, nor by Two walking together; he appeared to them All; upbraiding them with Ʋnbelief; after which, He Commiſſionated them to go forth Preaching to All Nations; enduing them with Gifts for their Office, and Power againſt unclean Spirits: after which, he gave them an Account of his Aſcenſion into Heaven.

div.trailer: The End of S. MARK.

div.head: S. LUKE.

p.hi: HOw doth S. LƲKE begin his Goſpel?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With an Account of John Baptiſt, who was our Saviour's Fore-runner, and declared him to be the MESSIAS.

p.hi: What Account is given of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
An Account of his Parentage,
Chap. 1 together with his miraculous Conception and Birth; upon which ſcore he is likened to Ezekiel's Ox.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who were John Baptiſt's Parents?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Zacharias and Elizabeth, both of the Tribe of Levi; and Zacharias a Prieſt, of the Order of Abias.

p.hi: What Character is given of them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That they were both Righteous, walking blameleſly before the Lord.

p.hi: What is declared concerning his Conception and Birth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Miraculouſneſs of them, by reaſon of his Parents Age, and the Diſcovery of that Miracle by an Angel.

p.hi: Of what Age were his Parents?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They were both ſtricken in years, and Elizabeth had no Child.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To whom was the Diſcovery made of John Baptiſt's Birth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Zacharias, who (according to his office) was then to burn Incenſe in the Temple.

p.hi: Ʋnder what Notion was this Diſcovery made?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That his Prayers being heard, his Wife ſhould bear a Son, who was appointed an Inſtrument of converting many Jews unto God.

p.hi: Who made this Diſcovery?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Angel Gabriel.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Zacharias entertain this Meſſage?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: with much Ʋnbelief; for which he was puniſhed by being ſtricken dumb; and ſo to continue till the accompliſhment of that Meſſage; to the admiration of the People who waited for him upon his long ſtay in the Temple.

p.hi: What was the next Errand whereupon this Angel was employed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Errand to the Bleſſed Virgin Mary, to acquaint her that ſhe ſhould be the MOTHER of our Saviour, by the miraculous power of the Holy Ghoſt, becauſe ſhe had never known man.

p.hi: What particular Taken was given to confirm her Faith herein?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Account of her Couſin Elizabeth's having conceived John the Baptiſt about ſix Months before, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What courſe did the Virgin Mary take to be further ſatisfied in the truth of this Relation.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
She went to her Couſin Elizabeth; upon whoſe Viſit the Child leaped in Elizabeths Womb for joy; and ſhe acknowledged
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
Mary as the Mother of her (and our) Lord; pronouncing a Bleſſing upon her for her Faith.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Mary entertain this Salutation?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With her Magnificat, a Song of Praiſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did Elizabeth bear a Son according to this Prediction?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She did.

p.hi: What was his Name?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Name was called JOHN.

p.hi: How came he be ſo called?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: His Friends would have Named him Zacharias, after his Father; but his Mother called him John: which Name (upon their Diſlike) was confirmed by his Father's writing it, though he could not ſpeak.

p.hi: Was his Father's Speech reſtored unto him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for immediately after theſe Signs made, he ſpake plainly.

p.hi: What was the firſt uſe he made of his Tongue?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Bleſſing God in his Benedictus, or Song of Praiſe.

p.hi: At what time happened our Saviour's Birth?
p.label: Chap. 2

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In the Days of Auguſtus Caeſar, when he ſet forth a Decree to Tax all Perſons under his Government.

p.hi: Where was Chriſt born?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In Bethlehem, according to the Propheſies which went of him.

p.hi: How came he to be born there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe Joſeph (his Reputed Father) went with Mary his Mother thither to obey Caeſar's Command, near the time when ſhe was to be Delivered.

p.hi: Where was he laid upon his Birth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was wrapped in Swadling-cloaths, and laid in a Manger, in the Stable, becauſe there was no room for his Parents in the Inne.

p.hi: To whom was the firſt Declaration of his Birth made?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Shepherds in the Field, who were watching their Flocks by Night.

p.hi: By whom was it made?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By an Angel of God; with a Sign where and how they ſhould find him.

p.hi: How was this Meſſage accompanied?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a Divine Anthem, ſung by the Heavenly Hoſt.

p.hi: Did the Shepherds find the Relation given them to be true?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for according to the Command, they made Enquiry, going to Bethlehem, and finding it to be as the Angel had told them, they noiſed it abroad.

p.hi: Did Chriſt after his Birth ſubmit to the Ordinances of the Law?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for upon the Eighth day he was Circumciſed, and called Jeſus; and his Mother at the appointed time was Purified in the Temple, preſenting her Son there unto the Lord according to the Law; and offering what the Law required.

p.hi: Who was then to meet with them in the Temple?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Simeon, an Holy man; who (having a Divine Revelation that he ſhould not die till he had ſeen Chriſt in the Fleſh) came at that time, by the Spirit, into the Temple.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Simeon entertain this ſight?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He took the Child (JESƲS) in his Arms, bleſſed God with a Song (his Nunc Dimittis) and Propheſied of that Child's Sufferings.

p.hi: Whom elſe did they there meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Anna a Propheteſs, a conſtant Attender in the Temple, of almoſt an Hundred Years old; who thanked God, and Propheſied of the Redemption which that Child ſhould work.

p.hi: Whither did JESƲS his Parents go after theſe things were done?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Nazareth, the place of their Abode.

p.hi: At what time was Chriſt publickly taken notice of?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: When at Twelve Years old, being in Jeruſalem, at the Feaſt of the Paſsover, he went into the Temple, and Diſputed with the Doctors.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When did John Baptiſt begin to Preach and Baptize?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
In the Fifteenth Year of Tiberius Caeſar.
Chap. 3

p.hi: What became of him afterwards?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He was caſt into Priſon by Herod,
whom he had reproved for Ʋncleanneſs with Herodias his Brother Philip's Wife.

p.hi: Of what Age was Christ when he was Baptized, and began to Preach?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: About Thirty years of Age.

p.hi: What other things are remarkable in this Goſpel, which are not found in the Reſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several things, which ſhall be noted as they come in order.

p.hi: What is the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Chriſt's Preaching at Nazareth (where he had been brought up) upon a paſſage of the Prophet Iſaiah;
Chap. 4 declaring that Text to be then fulfilled in himſelf: and the effect that Sermon had upon the People.

p.hi: What was that Effect?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In ſome it wrought an Admiration; in others ſo much Wrath that they thruſt him out of the Synagogue, and would have thrown him headlong down the Brow of the Hill (whereon their City was built) had he not miraculouſly eſcaped from them.

p.hi: What was the Second?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Miracle by the Lake of Geneſareth; where entring into Simon's Ship,
Chap. 5 who had toiled all the night for Fiſh, and catched nothing, Chriſt commanded him to launch out, and that the Net ſhould be caſt out for a Draught; whereupon ſuch a multitude of Fiſhes were taken, that the Nets brake, and that Ship with another were ſo filled, that they both began to ſink.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What influence had this Miracle upon Peter and his Partners?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They were aſtoniſhed at the ſight; and Peter in an Extaſie, deſired Chriſt to depart from him, for he was a ſinful man.

p.hi: How did Chriſt comfort all of them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With an Aſſurance that (as Spiritual Fiſhers) they ſhould after that time catch men: and then they followed him.

p.hi: What was the Third Thing conſiderable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
After a Repetition of his Sermon (in ſhort) mentioned by S. Matthew,
Chap. 7 he raiſed to Life the Widows Son of Naim, who was upon carrying forth to be buried; comforting his Mother, and touching the Bier; upon which Touch, the young man aroſe alive.

p.hi: What was the Fourth Thing?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Story of Mary Magdalen in a Phariſees Houſe, waſhing Chriſt's Feet with her Tears, wiping them with the Hairs of her Head, kiſſing and anointing them with Ointment.

p.hi: What uſe did Chriſt make hereof in his Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He reproved the Phariſee (in whoſe Houſe he was) for a Miſs-conceit of his ſuffering this from ſo great a Sinner, by a Parable of Two Debtors, one owing little, the other much, and both forgiven; ſince he to whom much was forgiven would love moſt; and ſhe having much forgiven her, did this to expreſs the Greatneſs of her Affection.

p.hi: What follows next in courſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
An Account of our Saviour's going to Jeruſalem,
Chap. 9 when paſſing through a Village of the Samaritans, where they would not receive him, he denied the requeſt of James and John, about calling for Fire from Heaven to conſume them (after the example of Elias) teaching them that the Deſign of the Goſpel was not to deſtroy, but to ſave mens Lives.

p.hi: What comes in order after this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Lawyer's tempting Chriſt upon the account of the Commandments,
Chap. 10 and who was meant in the Law by his Neighbour.

p.hi: How did Chriſt explain this unto him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Parable of a man Travelling from Jeruſalem to Jericho, who was ſtripped and left wounded by Thieves; whom a Prieſt and Levite paſſed by; but a courteous Samaritan took upon his Beaſt, carried to an Inne, bound up his Wounds, and paid his Charges.

p.hi: How was this Applied?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt thereupon asked the Lawyer which of theſe Three was the Man's Neighbour; upon whoſe Anſwer [He that ſhewed Mercy] Chriſt directed him to do accordingly.

p.hi: What enſued hereupon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Entertainment which Chriſt had in Martha's Houſe; whom he commended for welcoming him, but her Siſter Mary
much more, for hearing his Word, and ſo chuſing the better part.

p.hi: To what doth our Saviour then proceed?
p.label: Chap. 11

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon the Requeſt of his Diſciples, who deſired he would teach them to pray, as John taught his Diſciples, he gave them [His moſt excellent Prayer] not only as a Pattern of Prayer, but as a Form of Prayer, teaching them to ſay, Our Father, &c.

p.hi: But what particularly did he tell them after the recital of this Prayer?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The neceſſity of being importunate in Prayer, by the Parable of a man in need, to ſupply a Friend, coming to borrow ſome Loaves, and gaining them upon the account of his earnestneſs; ſhewing that in the ſame manner God will deal with us.

p.hi: What occaſion did Chriſt take to diſſwade his Followers from worldly-mindedneſs?

sp.p: He did it upon the account of the Requeſt of a man entreating that he would divide the Inheritance between him and his Brother; in which dealing he acknowledged himſelf to be no Judge.

p.hi: What particular Argument did he uſe upon that occaſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To beware of Covetouſneſs; becauſe a man's Life conſiſteth not in the abundance of the things which he poſſeſſeth.

p.hi: How did he urge this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By a Parable, and by Reaſons.

p.hi: What was the Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Of a Rich man whoſe Grounds bringing forth plentifully, he reſolved to build greater Barns for the beſtowing his Fruits, and promiſed himſelf a great deal of Pleaſure, having Goods laid up for many years; but that very night God took his Soul from him.

p.hi: What Application did Chriſt make of this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Application is (ſo, i. e. a Fool) is every one that layeth up Treaſure for himſelf, and is not rich towards God.

p.hi: What were the Reaſons?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several; partly drawn from a Conſideration of the Inferior Creatures, Ravens, and Lillies, for whom God provided; partly from God's knowing our need of Outward things: but eſpecially from a Conſideration of the Heavenly Kingdom which he would give us, and conſequently that we ſhould not want any Neceſſary Outward Bleſſing.

p.hi: To what Head did Chriſt then turn his Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To the Doctrine of Repentance,
Chap. 13 upon occaſion of mentioning the Galileans, whoſe Blood Pilate mingled with their Sacrifices, and the Eighteen ſlain by the Tower of Siloam's falling upon them.

p.hi: Wherein lay the ſtrength of this Argument?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That men ſhould not think the perſons upon whom thoſe Judgments fell, to be extraordinary Sinners; but that without Repentance all ſhould periſh.

p.hi: What particular Miracle happened after this Doctrine delivered?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Curing of a Woman of an Eighteen years Infirmity, by his Word, and laying his Hands upon her.

p.hi: How was this Miracle taken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Ruler of the Synagogue was angry, and chode with the Woman, becauſe it was done on the Sabbath Day.

p.hi: What Anſwer did Chriſt make to this Rebuke?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He taxed the Ruler's Hypocriſie by an Argument of doing Works of Neceſſity to an Oxe or an Aſs; that this work of Charity was juſtifiable on that day, to a Daughter of Abraham.

p.hi: What was his next Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon a Queſtion asked, ſhewing the Fewneſs of thoſe that ſhould be ſaved; that men ſhould ſtrive for the Kingdom of God.

p.hi: What was hereupon urged against him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Relation of Herod's Deſign to kill him, that he might be fearful.

p.hi: What Miracle did he then do?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He healed a man of a Dropſie on the Sabbath; for which he gave thoſe Reaſons which the Phariſees were not able to anſwer.

p.hi: What Parable did he then ſpeak to them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Being at a Feaſt, to retrench their Ambition, and engage them to Humility, he propounded the Parable of Ʋndecency in mens chuſing the uppermoſt Seats in the Room, leſt they ſhould be deſired to ſit lower; but rather the loweſt, that they might be exalted higher.

p.hi: What eſpecial Direction did he give to the Inviter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That when he made a Feaſt, he ſhould not chuſe his Rich Friends and Neighbours, but the Poor and Impotent, to aſſure his Reward at the Reſurrection.

p.hi: What great Duty did he then urge upon All that would be his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Duty of Self-Denial; to quit all their Intereſts for him.

p.hi: How was it urged?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By propoſal of a ſerious Conſideration how they undertake his Service, in alluſion to a Man's building a Tower, who who would firſt compute the Charge, leſt he ſhould be laughed at for his Enterprize; and by one King's making War againſt another of double ſtrength, who would certainly overcome him.

p.hi: What occaſion was given to Chriſt for his next Parables?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Publicans and Sinners coming to hear him;
Chap. 15 at which the Scribes and Phariſees found fault.

p.hi: What Parables did he then make uſe of?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Four. The Firſt was indeed Two in One: That of the loſt ſheep; over which, the Owner, when he finds it, rejoyceth more than over the other Ninety nine (when he had an Hundred:) and of the Womans loſt Piece of Silver, over which (when found) ſhe joyeth more than over the others which had not been loſt at all.

p.hi: What was the Second Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Of a Prodigal Son; who having waſted his Portion in Riotous Living, returned to his Father, and was kindly received by him; at which, his Envious Brother being angry, the Father pacified him with a Declaration of his Brother's ſad condition, the Bettering whereof, was a Joy unto him.

p.hi: What was the Third Parable, and to whom ſpoken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
It was ſpoken particularly to his Diſciples;
Chap. 16 and it was of a Rich man's Steward, who having waſted his Maſter's Goods, and being accuſed for doing ſo, endeavoured to work Favour for himſelf with the Debtors, by bringing them to Eaſier Terms.

p.hi: What Application did Chriſt make of this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Partly to inform them, That the Children of this World are wiſer in their generation than the Children of Light; and partly to teach us that we ſhould make to our ſelves Friends of the Mammon of unrighteouſneſs.

p.hi: What was the Fourth Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Hiſtorical Parable of the Rich man, and Lazarus the Beggar.

p.hi: What is the Subſtance of that Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That the Rich man being ſumptuouſly arrayed, and deliciouſly fed every day, had a poor man came begging to his Door, to whom he denied the Crums from his Table; the Dogs licking his Sores; but the Beggar dying, was carried by Angels into Abraham's Boſom; the Rich man dying, was buried, and went to Hell.

p.hi: What then happened to this rich man?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Being in Torments, he lift up his Eyes, and ſeeing Lazarus in Abraham's Boſom, he deſired a drop of Water to cool his Tongue, becauſe he was tormented in Flames.

p.hi: Was his Petition granted?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. Becauſe that rich man had received Bleſſings in this Life; for the miſsimprovement whereof, he was then tormented.

p.hi: What was his next Requeſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That Lazarus might be ſent to his five Brethren, leſt they ſhould come to the ſame place of Torment where he was.

p.hi: What Argument did he uſe for the obtaining his Deſire?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That though Abraham told him they had
the Scriptures, yet a Meſſage delivered by one from the Dead, might work more upon them.

p.hi: Was this Requeſt of his granted?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It was not, Abraham aſſuring him, That if they believed not the Scriptures, they would not believe the Relation of One from the Dead.

p.hi: What Direction did Chriſt then give to his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Direction to avoid Malice againſt their Brethren,
Chap. 17 forgiving them upon a profeſſion of Repentance.

p.hi: What Miracle followed upon this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Cleanſing Ten Lepers.

p.hi: What was conſiderable in this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That though Ten were cleanſed, yet there was but One that gave Thanks to God for his Cure; and he was a Samaritan.

p.hi: What other Diſcourſe happened?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon the Phariſees Queſtion, when the Kingdom of God ſhould come, Chriſt admoniſhed his Diſciples againſt Security; from the Inſtance of the Old World, in the Dayes of Noah, deſtroyed with a Flood; and the People of Sodom, in the Dayes of Lot, deſtroyed with Fire and Brimſtone.

p.hi: What other Duty did Chriſt teach his Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Duty of Fervent and Importunate Prayer.
Chap. 18

p.hi: How did he teach it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By the Parable of an Ʋnjuſt Judge,
who was wrought upon by the importunity of a poor Widow, to revenge her of her Adverſary.

p.hi: How did Chriſt apply this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That if a Man could thus be prevailed with, much more would God be ſo, to take care of his Elect.

p.hi: What elſe was taught them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſhaking off all Self-Confidence?

p.hi: In what manner was this done?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Parable of a Phariſee and Publican going to Pray in the Temple; the Phariſee boaſting of his good Deeds; but the Publican humbly confeſſing his ſins; whereupon He was juſtified, but the Phariſee was not.

p.hi: What perſon do we read of that next entertained Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Zacheus the Publican.
Chap. 19

p.hi: How did he manifeſt his inclination to entertain him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Being Low of Stature, he climbed into a Sycamore-Tree to ſee him, as he paſſed along.

p.hi: Was this kindly taken by our Saviour?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: So kindly, that eſpying him in the Tree, he called him to come down, and proffered to be a Gueſt at his Houſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Repentance did Zacheus then ſhew for his former ſins?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Not only the Receiving of Chriſt joyfully, but declaring his Readineſs to give Half of his Goods to the Poor, and reſtoring Fourfold to any one whom he had wronged by falſe Accuſation.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Compaſſion did Chriſt ſhew to Jeruſalem, whither he was then going?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No ſooner did he ſee the City, but he wept, lamenting the Deſolation which ſhould come upon it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Particulars are here recorded concerning Chriſt's Paſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Exhortation which he gave to his Followers,
Chap. 23 that they ſhould not weep for him, but themſelves; the Praying for his Enemies; and the Converſion of the Penitent Malefactor, who juſtified Chriſt's Innocency when he died with him.

p.hi: What followed after his Faſſion, which is not elſewhere declared?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
His Diſcourſing with the Two Diſciples going to Emaus,
Chap. 24 expounding to them the Scriptures concerning himſelf, and being known unto them in Eating with them.

p.hi: Did he not likewiſe diſcover himſelf to the reſt of the Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for he appeared to them when they were together; making them to feel his Body; and Eating in their preſence.

p.hi: Did he not at that time give them ſome Promiſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He gave them the Promiſe of the Holy Ghoſt's being ſent, commanding them to ſtay at Jeruſalem till that Promiſe was fulfilled.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What was there remarkable in Chriſt's Aſcenſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That leading his Diſciples as far as
Bethany, he Bleſſed them, and while he did ſo, was carried from them into Heaven.

p.hi: What did the Diſciples do after his Aſcenſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They worſhipped him; returning to Jeruſalem with great Joy; continuing in the Temple, and praiſing God.

div.trailer: The End of S. LUKE.

div.head: S. JOHN.

p.hi: VVHo was the Writer of this Goſpel?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. JOHN, Chriſt's Beloved Diſciple.

p.hi: Doth he write of the ſame things with the other Evangeliſts?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for his principal Buſineſs being to convince thoſe of his time concerning Chriſt's Divinity, he purpoſely relates ſuch things as gave the moſt evident Proofs of it; whereupon he is compared to Ezekiel's Eagle.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What doth S. John's Firſt Chapter contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Declaration of Chriſt's Divinity,
Chap. 1 V. 1. his Humanity, V. 14. His Office, of being the Light of the World, V. 9. The Teſtimony given of him by John Baptiſt; the Calling of S. Andrew and S. Peter, Philip and Nathanael.

p.hi: What is the firſt Miracle of which this Evangeliſt ſpeaketh?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The turning Water into Wine at a Marriage in Cana in Galilee,
Chap. 2 which was indeed the Firſt of all the Miracles he wrought.

p.hi: How did he next diſcover himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By going into the Temple at the Paſsover, and driving out the Sellers of Sheep
and Oxen, with a Scourge of ſmall Cords.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What notice did the Jews then take of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They required a Sign from him to ſhew his Authority.

p.hi: What Sign did he give them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Sign of his own Paſſion and Reſurrection after three Days, with alluſion to the Deſtroying the Temple (meaning the Temple of his Body) which he in that time would rear again.

p.hi: What Favour did he gain with the People?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Many Believed on him upon the Account of his Miracles.

p.hi: Who is particularly mentioned?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Nicodemus,
Chap. 3 one of the Jewiſh Rulers, who came by night to diſcourſe with Chriſt.

p.hi: In what things did Chriſt principally inſtruct him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In the neceſſity of Regeneration, Salvation by Faith in Him, the unexpreſſible Love of God in ſending Chriſt into the World; and the great ground of Condemnation by Ʋnbelief.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Account did John Baptiſt give of Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some of his Diſciples acquainting their Maſter what Followers Chriſt had gained, John told them Who he was, and how he ſhould encreaſe.

p.hi: Whither did Chriſt then take his Journey?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Out of Judea into Galilee;
Chap. 4 paſſing by Sychar, a City of Samaria, where Jacob's Well was.

p.hi: What happened there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Diſcourſe which he had with a Samaritan Woman.

p.hi: Ʋpon what occaſion did this Diſcourſe begin?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon her coming to that Well to draw Water, he inſtructs her about the Water of Life; telling her likewiſe what her Converſation was in living with a Man who was not her Husband.

p.hi: What thoughts had the Woman of him upon this Relation?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She apprehendeth him to be a Prophet.

p.hi: How did his Diſciples take this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They having been employed about buying Meat in the City, were ſurprized at their return, to ſee Chriſt and the Woman talking together.

p.hi: What way did this Woman take to make Chriſt more known?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: She divulged him to the men of the City, as one that had told her all things ſhe had done; whereupon the People went out to ſee him, and by his Diſcourſe with them, many believed on him.

p.hi: What is the Second Miracle mentioned?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Healing a Nobleman's Son at Capernaum, who was ſick of a Fever.

p.hi: How was it known that Chriſt cured him?

sp.speaker: D.
