sp.p: Becauſe the Father of the Child deſiring this Favour from Chriſt, had his promiſe for the Cure; and by the Relation of his own Servants, at the very hour when the Promiſe was made, the Fever left him.

p.hi: What is the next Miracle recorded by this Evangeliſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Curing a Lame man,
Chap. 5 who had been troubled with his Infirmity 38 years.

p.hi: Ʋpon what occaſion was this Miracle wrought?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chriſt coming to one of the Solemn Feaſts at Jeruſalem, ſaw him lying at the Pool of Betheſda, and there Cured him.

p.hi: Why did the man lie there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe an Angel coming at ſuch a time, moved the Water, and gave it ſuch a virtue, that whoſoever firſt ſtepped in, was cured.

p.hi: When was this Cure wrought?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: On the Sabbath Day.

p.hi: What happened hereupon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two things. 1. The Jews chiding with the man for being healed on the Sabbath. 2. Their endeavouring to kill Chriſt for healing on that Day.

p.hi: What Anſwer did Chriſt make to juſtifie himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Beſides his ſolemn Reaſoning to their Cavils, he plainly proves himſelf to be the Meſſias, appealing to the Teſtimony of John Baptiſt, V. 33. To the Miracles which he wrought, V. 36. To the Voice of his Father,
owning him, V. 37. and to the Scriptures; V. 39. Referring them to Moſes, in whom they ſo much truſted.

p.hi: Doth not this Evangeliſt mention the Miracle of the Loaves and Fiſhes?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes;
Chap. 6 He relates the feeding 5000 men with Five Loaves and Two Fiſhes; adding further, that they were Barley Loaves; and that the Miracle was wrought at the Sea of Tiberias.

p.hi: What followed upon this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Peoples Reſolution to make him King; whereupon he departed to the other ſide of the Sea.

p.hi: Did any thing befal the Diſciples as they croſſed the Seas?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They being got into another Ship by themſelves, and being alſo in Danger, becauſe it was dark, were very much afraid; till Chriſt made himſelf known unto them, and ſo was received into their Ship.

p.hi: How was it with them when they came to Land?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The People which had ſeen the former Miracle, following him, he took occaſion from thence to diſcourſe with them about the true Living Bread, which was Himſelf.

p.hi: How did this Diſcourſe take?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It made a great many of his Followers depart from him, becauſe he ſpake of his Death, and Aſcenſion into Heaven.

p.hi: Where do we next meet with Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
At Jeruſalem,
Chap. 7 in the Feaſt of Tabernacles,
where he made another excellent Speech to the People.

p.hi: What Influence had this Speech upon them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It made many perſons acknowledge him to be the Chriſt.

p.hi: Did the Phariſees take this well?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. For they then ſent Officers to apprehend him; who being much affected with his Words, returned without him; which occaſioned a great Debate.

p.hi: What Project had they then againſt Chriſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They brought to him a Woman taken in Adultery, and ſetting her before him,
Chap. 8 deſired Judgment againſt her.

p.hi: Did Chriſt pronounce any ſentence againſt her?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. He writing upon the ground, that whoſoever was without ſin, ſhould caſt the firſt ſtone at her (ſtoning being the uſual Death for ſuch Offenders) all her Accuſers departed; and they being gone, he diſmiſſed her with a Charge to [SIN NO MORE.]

p.hi: What aroſe in controverſie upon this Diſmiſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A long Diſcourſe between Him and the Jews, till at length in Anger they deſigned to ſtone him; which he prevented by hiding himſelf, and paſſing through the midſt of them.

p.hi: What further proof did Chriſt give of his Divinity?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The curing a man blind from his Birth,
Chap. 2 by waſhing his Eyes in the Pool of Siloam, after he had anointed thoſe Eyes with Clay, made of Spittle.

p.hi: Did not this make the Neighbours of that man to wonder?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes. Whereupon the man told them who had recovered him of his Blindneſs.

p.hi: How did the Phariſees take this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They took the man into examination, and found fault with him for being healed on the Sabbath Day.

p.hi: How were they ſatisfied in the truth of the Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Not upon the man's Relation only, till they had called his Parents, who aſſerted that he was their Blind Son.

p.hi: What fell out upon that Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Diſcourſe between the Phariſees and the man that was cured; whereupon they excommunicated him, for defending Chriſt in his Cure.

p.hi: Did any injury happen to the man by this Sentence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for Chriſt hearing of it, did thereupon diſcover himſelf to the man, that he was the True Meſſias; and the man becoming one of his Diſciples, Chriſt entertained his Hearers with ſeveral Speeches.

p.hi: What was the Firſt of thoſe Speeches?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A ſhort Account of his Coming into the World for Judgment, and convincing them of wilful Blindneſs.

p.hi: What was the next?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Parable of the Good Shepherd,
Chap. 10 who took care of the Sheep, which the Hireling would not do.

p.hi: What did he mean by this Parable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That all Pretenders to the Meſſiah-ſhip before Himſelf, were no better than Hirelings (men led by worldly Principles) but He was the True Shepherd (or Meſſias.)

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Had this Parable no further reach than only with reſpect to the Jews?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; It related alſo to the Gentiles; becauſe he ſpeaks of the other Sheep which he muſt bring into his Fold; propheſying of his Reſurrection that ſhould be the means of bringing both Jews and Gentiles together.

p.hi: What effect had theſe Speeches upon the People?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There was a Diviſion; part of the People adhering unto, part diſſenting from him.

p.hi: At what time did this happen?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At the Feaſt of the Temples Dedication, when it was Winter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Queſtion did the Jews then ask him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whether he was the Chriſt or no?

p.hi: What Anſwer did he give them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Declaring his Miracles, he aſſerted himſelf to be One with the Father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did the Jews take that?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They threatned to ſtone him, till he proved the Reaſonableneſs of his Diſcourſe by a Quotation out of the Old
Teſtament, which he argued to his own Advantage.

p.hi: After Chriſt's eſcape from them, whither did he go?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To the other ſide of Jordan, where John had Baptized, and to which place many of the Jews reſorted to viſit him.

p.hi: What Acceptance had theſe Speeches at the laſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Different among the Jews; for ſome derided, and others believed on him, by reaſon of the Miracle; till at laſt there was an attempt to ſtone him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Evidence did he receive from thoſe Jews that he was the Meſſias.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They were ſo far convinced, as to acknowledge that though John did no Miracle, yet whatſoever John had ſaid of him, was true; whereupon many believed on him.

p.hi: What Miracle do we find recorded after theſe Speeches?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The raiſing Lazarus out of the Grave.
Chap. 11

p.hi: What Circumſtances attended this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several: There being an exact Hiſtorical Narration of it.

p.hi: Pray declare the Particulars from the beginning.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It begins with the Account of Lazarus his being ſick, who was beloved of Chriſt (to whom his Siſters ſent word of his Illneſs) and then proceeds to his Death.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What notice did Chriſt take when he heard that Lazarus was ſick?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is ſaid, that upon hearing thereof, he abode two days in the place where he was, before he went to viſit Lazarus, for the Glory of his Majeſty; and then he told his Diſciples that Lazarus was dead.

p.hi: How did Chriſt then diſpoſe of himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He viſited Martha (Lazarus his Siſter) and comforted her with hope of her Brother's Reſurrection; but ſhe (and her Siſter Mary) not contented therewith, after he had wept over Lazarus his Grave, He raiſed him from the dead, by the word of his Mouth, when he had been four Days buried.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Lazarus ariſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With his Grave-cloaths about him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did this Miracle work upon the Jews?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some believed; but others made it matter of their Diſcourſe to the Phariſees, for the rendring him odious, leſt by his means the Romans ſhould increaſe their Power.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What followed upon this Information given by thoſe Jews?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Conſultation was held to put Chriſt to Death (and not only Him, but Lazarus alſo) whereupon they ſought for him at the Feaſt of the Paſsover.

p.hi: Who gave Counſel for the doing of this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Caiaphas the High Prieſt; alledging that it was more expedient one man ſhould die, than that the whole Nation ſhould ſuffer.

p.hi: Whither did Chriſt then go?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Unto a City called Ephraim, near the Wilderneſs of Judea.

p.hi: How did Chriſt manifeſt himſelf at the Paſsover?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 12 Certain Greeks deſiring to ſee him, which they did by the Intereſt of Andrew and Philip, heard his Diſcourſe, and a Witneſs was given to him by a voice from Heaven.

p.hi: Did this work upon them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. They ſtill perſiſted in Ʋnbelief; whereupon he teſtified againſt them.

p.hi: What ſignal favour did Chriſt ſhew to the Diſciples before his ſuffering?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He took a Baſon of water (after Supper) and girding himſelf with a Towel,
Chap. 13 waſhed their feet, to teach them Humility and Condeſcention one towards another.

p.hi: Did he then give them any particular Command?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; the Command of Mutual Love, whereby they might teſtifie to the World their being his true Diſciples.

p.hi: How did he conclude all his former Sayings and Miracles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 14,15, 16, 17 With an excellent Farewel Sermon; exhorting them to Piety, Charity, Fruitfulneſs and Patience; ending with a fervent Prayer, both for his own Glorification, and the Salvation of all thoſe, who ſhould believe on him to the end of the World.

p.hi: Whither went he when this Sermon and Prayer were ended?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To the Brook Cedron, into a Garden,
whither he often reſorted, and there he was betrayed by Judas; and delivered into the hands of the Jews.

p.hi: Whither was he then carried?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Firſt to Caiaphas, afterwards to Pilate's Judgment-Hall; by whom he was condemned, and then crucified with an Inſcription over his head in Greek, Latin and Hebrew [Jeſus of Nazareth the King of the Jews.

p.hi: What was done to him after his Crucifixion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One of the Souldiers with a Spear pierced his ſide, out of which iſſued Water and Blood.

p.hi: What Particulars doth this Evangeliſt relate about his Reſurrection?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 20 Peter's and John's running to the Sepulchre, and there beholding the Grave-cloaths left behind, with the Napkin which had been about his Head, lying in a place diſtant from the reſt.

p.hi: To whom did Chriſt firſt appear after he was riſen?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Mary Magdalene, who took him to be the Gardner, till he diſcovered himſelf by his voice; afterwards ſhe proffered to embrace him; for which attempt ſhe was reproved.

p.hi: Did he not likewiſe appear to the other Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He appeared to them the ſame day at evening, and there with his Breath beſtowed upon them the Holy Ghoſt; giving
them power of remitting and retaining ſins.

p.hi: Were any of the Diſciples then abſent?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thomas was not there; nor would he believe the Relation, without ſatisfying himſelf by feeling the print of the Nails which had pierced him.

p.hi: Was this ſatisfaction afforded him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It was. For Eight days after, Chriſt appeared again, and allowed Thomas the liberty of feeling his Hands, Feet and Side; whereupon he cried out [My Lord and my God]

p.hi: Did he after this appear to his Diſciples any more?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes. He appeared to them again at the Sea of Tiberias.

p.hi: What Circumſtances attended that Appearance?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Peter, and ſome other Diſciples, going a Fiſhing, and catching nothing all night, in the Morning Jeſus ſtood on the Shore, and commanded them to caſt the Net on the Right ſide of the Ship, whereupon they caught ſuch a multitude of Fiſhes, that they were not able to draw the Net to ſhore.

p.hi: Did this make any Diſcovery of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. John hereupon declared to Peter, that it was the Lord; which Peter hearing, ſwam unto him; and the reſt of the Diſciples came in a little Ship, dragging the Net with Fiſhes.

p.hi: What Miracle followed this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No ſooner were they come aſhore, but they found a Fire of Coals with Fiſh laid upon it and Bread.

p.hi: Did they eat of the Fiſh?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. For at Chriſt's Command, they dreſſed of the Fiſh which they had taken.

p.hi: What Number of Fiſhes were taken at that Draught?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Hundred Fifty and Three Great Fiſhes; yet was not the Net broken.

p.hi: To whom did Chriſt then particularly addreſs himſelf in Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Peter, three times queſtioning his Love; which, when Peter profeſſed, as the beſt evidence thereof, Chriſt commanded him to feed his Lambs and Sheep; declaring alſo the Martyrdom that he ſhould ſuffer.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did Peter propound any Queſtion at that time to his Maſter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He asked what ſhould become of John.

p.hi: How did Chriſt anſwer this Queſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That if he pleaſed to have John live till his coming (i. e. till his Power was manifeſted in the Deſtruction of the Jews) it was nothing to him; whereupon the Diſciples fancied that John ſhould not die.

p.hi: How doth this Goſpel conclude.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With John's aſſerting the Truth of thoſe things which are delivered in it.

div.trailer: The End of S. JOHN.

div.head: ACTS.

p.hi: VVHat Book follows next after the Goſpels?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Acts of the Apoſtles.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why hath it that Name?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe it contains an Hiſtory of the Eminent Acts (beſide the Sufferings) of the Apoſtles of Chriſt, eſpecially thoſe Two more greatly employed, S. Peter and S. Paul.

p.hi: By whom was this Book written?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is generally believed to be written by S. Luke.

p.hi: What reaſon have we to believe ſo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Several Reaſons; particularly theſe Two. 1. Becauſe the Stile of this Book is the ſame with that of his Goſpel; (as thoſe who underſtand the Greek Tongue well,
Chap. 1 know.) 2. By the Reference it hath to the End of his Goſpel formerly written; and both of them are dedicated to the ſame Theophilus.

p.hi: Wherewith doth this Book begin?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a particular Account of Chriſt's Aſcenſion into Heaven, in the ſight of his Apoſtles, after he had converſed with them forty days from his Reſurrection.

p.hi: What was the firſt Work of the Apoſtles after Chriſt's Reſurrection?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They and the reſt of the Believers being aſſembled together, choſe one out of the other Diſciples, to ſucceed Judas in his Apoſtleſhip,
from which he fell by his Tranſgreſſion.

p.hi: Who were appointed to ſtand for the place?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two. Judas called Barſabas, and Matthias.

p.hi: How were they to be choſen?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Lot, and Prayer adjoyned.

p.hi: Ʋpon whom did the Lot fall?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon Matthias; who was thence-for-ward reckoned among the 11 Apoſtles.

p.hi: When was the Holy Ghoſt given to the Diſciples?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Upon the Feaſt of Pentecoſt,
Chap. 2 when they were all aſſembled together.

p.hi: How was He given?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With the ſound of a ruſhing mighty Wind, in Cloven Tongues like Fire, by which help they ſpake in ſeveral Languages.

p.hi: How was this great Gift entertained?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By ſome with ſcorn, as if the Apoſtles had been drunk; by others with wonder.

p.hi: How were the Apoſtles vindicated from the Aſperſion of being drunk?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By a good and eloquent Sermon of S. Peter's making.

p.hi: What eſpecial Argument did he uſe to vindicate them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He declared that hereby was fulfilled a Propheſie of Joel; and thereupon proved Chriſt to be the True Meſſias.

p.hi: Did this Sermon work effectually upon the People?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; for they were pricked at the heart, and three thouſand Souls were converted.

p.hi: In what manner did thoſe Converts live?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In great Ʋnity among themſelves; in great Devotion towards God, and ſuch Charity to one another, that they had all things common; inſomuch that they who had Poſſeſſions, ſold them for the relief of their Brethren in neceſſity.

p.hi: What was the firſt particular Miracle wrought after Chriſt's Aſcenſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Cure of a Lame man at the Beautiful Gate of the Temple, by the Word of S. Peter.

p.hi: What followed upon this Miracle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The People being amazed, S. Peter made another Sermon to convince them of their Duty in repenting for their Murder of Chriſt, and to receive him by a true Faith.

p.hi: What elſe followed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Chief of the Jews hearing this, put Peter (and John his Companion) into Priſon.

p.hi: What Number of Converts was already gained?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: About Five Thouſand.

p.hi: What Courſe did the Chief Prieſts and Rulers take with the Two Apoſtles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They enquired by what Name and Power that Miracle was wrought.

p.hi: What Anſwer was given to this Queſtion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Peter (who made the Anſwer) told them the Miracle was wrought in the Name of Chriſt; aſſerting him to be the true and only Saviour.

p.hi: How was this Anſwer taken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Rulers marvelled at the Boldneſs of the Apoſtles, and putting them aſide conſulted together what to do with them.

p.hi: How ended this Conſultation?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They let the Apoſtles go with threatnings, that they ſhould not ſpread the Name of Chriſt.

p.hi: Of what Age was the man that was healed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: About Forty years old.

p.hi: What did the Apoſtles do upon their Diſmiſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At their return they reported what had happened; whereupon followed a general Praiſing of God, and an entire Love among themſelves, manifeſted in the Relief given to thoſe who wanted, by ſelling their Poſſeſſions to ſupply one anothers Neceſſities.

p.hi: How was the Money diſpoſed of for which thoſe Poſſeſſions were ſold?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It was brought and laid at the feet of the Apoſtles.

p.hi: Was this Order juſtly obſerved by All?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
No.
Chap. 5 For Ananias and Saphira his wife kept back part of the Money for which their Land was ſold.

p.hi: How went it with them for doing ſo?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Peter taxed them with Hypocriſie; and they were both puniſhed for it by ſudden Death.

p.hi: Did the Apoſtles work any more Miracles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several: In Curing Sick People who were laid upon Beds and Couches in the Streets as they paſſed by; being brought to Jeruſalem from many places in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Were not the Jews angry at theſe Miracles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Sadduces (eſpecially) among them were; and put the Apoſtles into the common Priſon.

p.hi: How were they delivored out of Priſon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By an Angel of God opening the Priſon-Doors, and commanding them to preach in the Temple, which Command they obeyed.

p.hi: What courſe was taken when they were gone out of Priſon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Council met, and they were ſent for; but not being found, the Officers informed how cloſe the Priſon-doors were ſhut, and how carefully the Keepers were attending; upon which the Council hearing of their being in the Temple, brought them back to the place where they were, by Officers, but without violence, for fear the People ſhould ſtone them.

p.hi: What Anſwer did the Apoſtles make for themſelves, having received a charge not to Preach any more?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Peter (in the Name of the reſt) urged God's Command in their Vindication.

p.hi: What Puniſhment was then allotted them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nothing leſs than Death.

p.hi: How was that Puniſhment prevented?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the wiſe Counſel of Gamaliel; and then they were only beaten.

p.hi: How did the Apoſtles take this Puniſhment?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a great deal of Joy and Conſtancy in their work of Preaching, both in the Temple, and in private Houſes.

p.hi: What further ſettlement was then made of the Church?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Chap. 6 The Multitude of the Diſciples increaſing, Seven Deacons were choſen to take care of the Poor, whilſt the Diſciples attended upon Prayer, and Teaching the People.

p.hi: What were the Names of thoſe Seven?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Stephen, Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenor and Nicolas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Character is given of Stephen?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That he was a man full of the Holy Ghoſt, and that he wrought great Miracles.

p.hi: What Adverſaries were raiſed up againſt him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Synagogue of the Libertines, and others, diſputing with him; though they could not withſtand the Power by which he ſpake.

p.hi: How did they then contrive againſt him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſet up Falſe Witneſſes to accuſe him of Blaſphemy againſt the Law, and the Temple, upon which ſcore he was brought before the Council.

p.hi: How did he there defend himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
His Defence was by a long Speech;
Chap. 7 ſhewing God's goodneſs to the Jews, from Abraham's time to Solomon's, in an Hiſtorical Relation of what happened: impleading them on this very ſcore for not believing in Chriſt.

p.hi: Did they take this well from him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. They were cut to the heart, and they gnaſhed upon him with their Teeth.

p.hi: What Puniſhment did they inflict upon him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſtoned him to death, whilſt he prayed for them; (as well as himſelf) and they laid down their cloaths at the feet of Saul.

p.hi: In what caſe was the Church after his Death?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A great Perſecution began;
Chap. 8 and the Diſciples (except the Apoſtles) were all diſperſed abroad in ſeveral places.

p.hi: Who was mainly inſtrumental in this Perſecution?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Saul; who made havock of the Church; impriſoning divers both Men and Women.

p.hi: What Place did firſt receive the Goſpel?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The City of Samaria, by the Preaching of Philip; together with the Miracles which he wrought in caſting out unclean Spirits, and healing the Diſeaſed.

p.hi: Ʋpon whom eſpecially did he ſhew this miraculous Power?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon Simon the Sorcerer (commonly called Simon Magus) mightily eſteemed by the people, bewitched with his Sorcery; for he Believed and was Baptized.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did the Church at Jeruſalem entertain the News of Samaria's Converſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſent the Apoſtles Peter and John to lay hands upon them, that they might receive the Holy Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What advantage would Simon have made of this Power?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He ſeeing ſuch a Miracle wrought, would have bought the ſame Power with Money of the Apoſtles; upon which, S. Peter curſed his Deſign, and declared his wickedneſs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What became of Philip after this Converſion of the Samaritans?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was by the appointment of an Angel directed towards Gaza, where he Inſtructed and Baptized an Ethiopian Eunuch, employed in his Chariot with reading the Propheſie of Iſaiah; and then (being caught away by the Spirit) paſſed from Azotus, preaching in the ſeveral Cities till he came to Ceſarea.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
What happened to Saul the great Perſecuter of the Church?
Chap. 9

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: As he went to Damaſcus with Letters for perſecuting the Believers, he was ſtruck down to the earth, and had a Diſcovery of Chriſt, who declared the Perſecution to be made againſt himſelf.

p.hi: How was it then with him and his Company?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The reſt were ſtruck ſpeechleſs, he blind for three days; and commanded into the City, where Ananias was ſent to him, who reſtored his Sight to him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ʋpon what account did Ananias go to him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God appearing to Ananias, ſent him to Saul, (notwithſtanding his Excuſes) upon whoſe coming, the Scales ſell from Saul's eyes, and being declared God's Choſen Veſſel to the Gentiles, he received Meat, and was ſtrengthened.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Paul imploy himſelf upon his Converſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In Preaching Chriſt boldly, to the admiration of all who had formerly known him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Were the Jews pleaſed with this alteration in Saul?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for they conſulted to kill him; but the Deſign was prevented by the Diſciples letting him down in a Basket from the Wall of Damaſcus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither did Saul go from thence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Jeruſalem; where the Brethren knowing what he had been, were unwilling to entertain him, till Barnabas made way for it, by declaring his Converſion; upon which Relation, he was received, and ſent to Tarſus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Miracles were about that time wrought by S. Peter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
One upon Aeneas at Lydda, who had
kept his Bed Eight Years with a Palſie, and immediately cured; another at Joppa upon Tabitha (otherwiſe called Dorcas) whom he raiſed from the Dead.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Meſſage (for further Service) did he receive at Joppa?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Meſſage from Cornelius,
Chap. 10 a devout Centurion, ſent unto him by the direction of an Angel, and diſpatched by Two of Cornelius his Servants.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How was this Meſſage firſt ſignified to Peter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Cornelius being a Gentile, it was ſignified by a Viſion (in Peter's Trance) of a Veſſel wherein were ſeveral Creatures, unclean as well as clean, with a Command to eat of them; and this was ſhewed three times.

p.hi: What was this Viſion to ſignifie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Converſion of the Gentiles, at that time thought the unclean of the World.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How came Peter thus to underſtand the Viſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: While he thought upon it, the men from Cornelius enquired for him, with whom he went to Ceſarea, through a Divine Inſpiration.

p.hi: What entertainment had he there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Cornelius meeting, would have worſhipped him, which he denied; declaring the Viſion (upon the account whereof he came.) And at his Preaching Chriſt, the whole Company had the Holy Ghoſt fell upon them, and were Baptized,
with whom he ſtayed certain dayes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How was this Action taken by the Jewiſh Converts?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They were angry at his going to a Gentile,
Chap. 11 till he declared the Viſion, with the occaſion of it, and then they glorified God for his Mercy to the Gentiles.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What became of the Diſciples ſcattered abroad upon the Perſecution raiſed at Stephen's Death?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They travelled through ſeveral Countries, ſetling at laſt at Antioch, where many were converted.

p.hi: What care was taken of theſe new Converts?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Church at Jeruſalem ſent Barnabas to ſtrengthen them in the Faith, who afterwards went to ſeek Saul at Tarſus, and brought him thither.

p.hi: Had the Diſciples any particular Name given them in that place?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They were in that place firſt called Chriſtians.

p.hi: What particular Propheſie do we then meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Propheſie from Agabus, concerning the Dearth which happened in the Dayes of Claudius Caeſar, whereupon the Diſciples ſent Relief into Judea, by Barnabas and Saul.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did King Herod behave himſelf all this while?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He being an enemy to the Church,
Chap. 12 killed James the Brother of John, and put
Peter in Priſon, deſigning his Death alſo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By what means was Peter delivered?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By an Angel, carrying him paſt ſeveral Watches through the Iron Gate into the Street, where he was left; and went to the Houſe of John called Mark.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Puniſhment afterwards befel Herod?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Making an eloquent Oration one day, for which he was highly applauded, the Angel of God ſmote him, and he was eaten up of Worms, becauſe he gave not God the Glory.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Cornelius being converted, was no care taken of the other Gentiles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes.
Chap. 13 Barnabas and Saul (afterwards called Paul) were by God's command, ſeparated for the employment of converting them, with Faſting, Prayer, and Impoſition of Hands.

p.hi: What was the firſt oppoſition theſe Two Apoſtles met with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It was from a Jewiſh Sorcerer at Paphos; Elymas by Name.

p.hi: What Puniſhment befel him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was according to Paul's word, ſtruck blind for a certain time.

p.hi: What influence had this Miracle upon others?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It particularly made the Deputy of that Countrey to Believe.

p.hi: What elſe happened remarkable?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
They Preaching Chriſt at Antioch, ſome Jews and Gentiles alſo Believed, and
deſired the ſame Diſcourſe might be delivered to them the next abbath; which the other Jews oppoſing, the Apoſtles left them, going among the Gentiles to Iconium.

p.hi: What befel them there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The unbelieving Jews ſtirred up the people againſt them,
Chap. 14 ſo that they were forced to flee to Lyſtra.

p.hi: What happened there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Paul healed a born-Cripple; whereupon the People would have Sacrificed to him and Barnabas, which they refuſed; but afterwards by the inſtigation of the Jews who came thither, Paul was ſtoned; yet after his miraculous recovery, they both returned to Antioch.

p.hi: What other Troubles did they meet with at this time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Some Teachers would have impoſed upon the Diſciples a neceſſity of Circumciſion,
Chap. 15 in order to Salvation.

p.hi: What was reſolved upon when this Queſtion was ſtarted?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That Paul and Barnabas with others, ſhould be ſent to the Apoſtles and Elders at Jeruſalem, to have their Opinion about it.

p.hi: What did thoſe Elders declare upon the hearing it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Being aſſembled together in Council, they declared that Circumciſion was not neceſſary; and only commanded an abſtinence from certain things, ſending Letters to the ſame purpoſe throughout the Churches.

p.hi: What were thoſe things to be abſtained from?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Four: Meats offered to Idols, Blood, Things ſtrangled, and Fornication.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did Paul and Barnabas continue together after this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They did for ſome time, but at length a Quarrel happening, they parted.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither did Paul go then?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He was called into Macedonia by a Viſion,
Chap. 16 and went to Philippi, where he converted Lydia, and caſt a Spirit of Divination out of a Damoſel; upon which, he and Silas (his Companion) were put into Priſon.

p.hi: What Miracle was wrought during their Impriſonment?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſinging Praiſes to God at Midnight, there happened a great Earthquake, which threw open the Priſon-doors; whereupon the Jaylor was affrighted, and ready to kill himſelf, fearing he had loſt his Priſoners.

p.hi: How was he hindred from that purpoſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Paul's calling to him, and preaching Faith in Chriſt; whereupon he believed; and himſelf with his whole Houſhold was Baptized.

p.hi: How long were theſe Perſons kept in Priſon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Magiſtrates of the Town entreated them the next day to depart.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To what place went Paul next that is of Note?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
After ſome Journeys he came to Theſſalonica,
Chap. 17
where he Preached, and ſome perſons Believed.

p.hi: How was he entertained there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The unbelieving Jews occaſioning a Tumult, aſſaulted Jaſon's Houſe, and alledging they were enemies to Caeſar, perſecuted Paul till he went to Berea.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did the Bereans carry themſelves?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Hearing Paul preach in the Jewiſh Synagogue, they ſearched the Scriptures, to try the Agreement between them and his Doctrine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither did Paul journey from Berea?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Athens; where he encountred with the Epicureans and Stoicks.

p.hi: What obſervable thing did he there meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Inſcription upon an Altar, To the Ʋnknown God; upon which occaſion, he Preached Chriſt, and the Reſurrection from the Dead.

p.hi: How was this Doctrine entertained?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With Scoffes by ſome; and with Faith by others.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither did Paul go from Athens?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To Corinth;
Chap. 18 where he met with Aquila, a Jew (baniſhed by Claudius the Emperor from Rome) and his Wife Priſcilla, lately come from Italy.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Encouragement had Paul at Corinth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God told him in a Viſion that he ſhould not be diſheartned, becauſe there were many people belonging to God in that City.

p.hi: What Troubles began then to fall upon him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was accuſed before Gallio the Deputy of Achaia, but diſmiſſed; whereupon the Jews being enraged, fell to beating Soſthenes the Ruler of the Synagogue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither journeyed he from Corinth?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Cenchrea for the paying his Vow, and thence to Epheſus.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Company did Paul meet with at Epheſus?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One Apollos a Jew, eloquent, and well read in the Scriptures; who diſputed with the Jews, and being further inſtructed by Aquila and Priſcilla, ſtrongly aſſerted that Jeſus was the Chriſt.

p.hi: What other Company did he meet with?
p.label: Chap. 19

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some Diſciples (about Twelve in Number) who not knowing any thing of the Holy Ghoſt's being given, were Baptized in the Name of Jeſus, and by the Impoſition of Paul's hands, had the Holy Ghoſt given unto them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did the Jews there entertain his Doctrine?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With ill words; inſomuch that he took his Diſciples into the School of Tyrannus, where he continued for Two years, working ſeveral Miracles upon Sick Perſons.

p.hi: What particular oppoſition did he there meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Certain Exorciſts, pretending in his Name to call upon Evil Spirits, were aſſaulted
by thoſe Spirits, and fled for their ſecurity; whereupon followed a Confeſſion from them, and the burning their Conjuring Books to a great value.

p.hi: Whom had he elſe to deal with there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With Demetrius a Silver-Smith, and ſeveral others, who made an Ʋproar in the City, finding their gains were gone; their employment being to make Shrines for their Goddeſs Diana; which Uproar, by the perſwaſion of their Town-Clerk, was at length appeaſed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where do we meet with Paul's next Miracle?
At Philippi; for there he raiſed Eutychus to life, who had fallen down dead as Paul was long Preaching.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Where did Paul make any ſtay after he went from Philippi?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: At Mil •• us; where ſending for the Elders of the Church of Epheſus, he gave them a Godly Exhortation, to attend their Duty; Propheſying what Troubles ſhould ariſe, and declaring his expectation not to ſee them any more; which occaſioned a great deal of Sorrow among them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whither did Paul then go?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Jeruſalem; from which Journey he was much diſſwaded.

p.hi: What particular diſcouragement had he from undertaking that Journey?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Coming to Ceſarea, into the Houſe of Philip the Evangeliſt, Agabus a Prophet met him there, who binding himſelf with Paul's
Girdle, propheſied how the Jews ſhould bind him, whoſe it was, at Jeruſalem.

p.hi: What did the Diſciples ſay to this Propheſie?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They did with Tears renew their Requeſt to Paul, that he would not go thither.

p.hi: Was he wrought upon hereby?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No. He flatly denied them, profeſſing his willingneſs not only to be Bound, but to Die alſo at Jeruſalem for the Name of Jeſus; upon which, they reſted content.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Who bore him company to Jeruſalem?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Mnaſon, an old Diſciple, with whom he was to lodge.

p.hi: To whom did he apply himſelf at his coming thither?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To the Diſciples, whom he informed of the Gentiles Converſion by his means.

p.hi: What Advice did they give him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That to ſhew his Obedience to the Law, whereof the Believing Jews there were very zealous, he ſhould purifie himſelf in the Temple, with other men who were under a Vow.

p.hi: What befel him upon the following this advice?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: When he came to do it, the Jews aſſaulted him, and attempted to ſlay him, after he was ſorely beaten.

p.hi: How was he reſcued?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By the Chief Captain (with his Souldiers) who bound him with Chains, and carried him into the Caſtle; where (upon the Stairs) he had liberty to ſpeak in his own defence.

p.hi: What Defence did he make?

sp.p: He ſpake to the Jews in their own Language, declaring his Converſion; which they patiently heard till he told of his being ſent to the Gentiles; and upon that word, they made an uproar againſt him, as one not fit to live.

p.hi: What then became of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He was remanded to the Caſtle, and Charge given to examine him by Scourging.

p.hi: How was this Puniſhment avoided?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By his declaring himſelf to be a Freeborn Roman; upon which account he was eaſed of his Bonds, that he might have a new Hearing?

p.hi: Before whom was that Hearing?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Before Ananias the High Prieſt, to whom he profeſſed his Innocency in all things.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did Ananias receive that Profeſſion?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He commanded Paul to be ſmitten on the Mouth.

p.hi: What Party did Paul make in the Multitude then gathered together?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Perceiving ſome to be Phariſees, and ſome Sadduces, he declared the Cauſe in queſtion to be a maintaining the Doctrine of the Reſurrection; upon which the Phariſees adhered to him.

p.hi: Why did they only adhere to him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe the Sadduces believed not any Reſurrection, nor Angel nor Spirit.

p.hi: How was this Commotion between the Two Parties appeaſed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Chief Captain fearing leſt any Injury ſhould befal him, ſent Souldiers to bring him by force into the Caſtle.

p.hi: What encouragement had he at that time?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: God's Angel comforted him, and told him he muſt bear the ſame witneſs of the Doctrine of Chriſt at Rome, as he had done at Jeruſalem.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Were the Jews quieted herewith?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; for more than Forty of them made a Conſpiracy againſt Paul's Life, pretending to deſire a further hearing of his Cauſe, and laying wait to kill him in the way as he ſhould come to his trial.

p.hi: How was this Plot prevented?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Paul's Siſters Son, hearing, diſcovered it to Paul, by whom he was ſent to the Captain to inform him; and for Paul's ſecurity, the Captain ſent him by night to Caeſarea.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What courſe did the Jews then take againſt him?
The High Prieſt and Elders came down to accuſe him before Felix the Governor, which they did by the Tongue of Tertullus an eminent Orator.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Had not Paul liberty to defend himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; and did ſo, by giving an Account of his Life and Doctrine.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did he Preach any more before Felix?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He did; for Felix's Wife Druſilla (being a Jeweſs) deſired to hear him; and
before them both he diſcourſed of Righteouſneſs, Temperance, and the Judgment to come.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How did this Diſcourſe work upon Felix?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It made him tremble; but he diſmiſſed Paul till a more convenient ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why would not Felix releaſe him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe he expected a Bribe; which failing, he delivered over Paul as a Priſoner to Feſtus, who ſucceeded him in the Government.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Did the Jews ſtill perſecute Paul?
Yes; they incenſed Feſtus againſt him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Reply did Feſtus make when they charged him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He commanded Paul's Accuſers to charge him at Caeſarea, where he was brought before the Judgment-Seat, and made his Appeal to Caeſar.

p.hi: Before whom did he next defend himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Before Agrippa and Bernice his Wife who came down to viſit Feſtus; to whom h • declared Paul's Caſe; and Agrippa deſire • to hear him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What was the Subſtance of Paul's Diſcourſe?
A Relation of his Life from his Childhood; the Miraculouſneſs of his Converſion and his acting according to the Command he then received from God.

p.hi: What Influence had this Diſcourſe upo • the Hearers of it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A different Influence; for Feſtus charged him with Madneſs, and Agrippa was almoſt perſwaded to be a Chriſtian; declaring withal that Paul might have been freed if he had not appealed unto Caeſar.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What then became of Paul?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He was ſhipped for a Voyage to Rome;
Chap. 27 in which Voyage a ſevere Storm fell upon the whole Company (his foretelling it not being believed) inſomuch that they were all in danger of being caſt away.

p.hi: How were they comforted in this extremity?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Paul related to them the Appearance of an Angel, who aſſured him of all their Lives, only that their Ship ſhould be loſt; upon which, after Fourteen days Faſting, they were perſwaded to eat.

p.hi: How many were there in the Ship?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Two Hundred Seventy and Six perſons.

p.hi: Where did they Land when the Ship was broken?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
In an Iſland called Melita.
Chap. 28

p.hi: What Entertainment did they there meet with?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They found a great deal of Reſpect; for the Barbarous People treated them with Fire becauſe of the Cold.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Accident happened there unto Paul?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: As he was gathering Sticks, a Viper faſtned upon his Hand.

p.hi: What did the People think when they ſaw it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They ſuppoſed him to be a Murderer, whom (though he had eſcaped the Sea, yet) Divine vengeance would not ſuffer to live.

p.hi: Did the Viper do him any harm?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; he ſhook it off into the Fire, and felt not any hurt.

p.hi: What did the People then think of him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They changed their minds, and ſaid that he was a God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What eſpecial Miracle did Paul work there?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He healed the Father of Publius (a Great man in that Iſland) of a Fever and a Bloudy Flux; and after him, others alſo who came unto him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What did he do when he came to Rome?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He called together the Chief of the Jews, to whom he declared the Cauſe of his coming thither, and at their appointment Preached Chriſt one day unto them.

p.hi: How was his Preaching received?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some believed, and others did not; whereupon he diſmiſſed the Aſſembly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How long did Paul dwell there, and how was he employed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He dwelt there two whole years, Preaching the Kingdom of God, and declaring the Doctrine of Chriſt.

div.trailer: The End of the ACTS.

p.hi: HOw many are there of the Canonical Epiſtles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One and Twenty.

p.hi: By whom were they written?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: St. Paul wrote Fourteen, St. James One, S. Peter Two, St. John Three, St. Jude One.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What were thoſe of St. Paul's Writing?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: One to the Romans, Two to the Corinthians, One to the Galatians, One to the Epheſians, One to the Philippians, One to the Coloſſians, Two to the Theſſalonians, Two to Timothy, One to Titus, One to Philemon, and one to the Hebrews.

p.hi: Were theſe Epiſtles written in the ſame Order as they are placed in our Books?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No; it is generally believed they were not.

p.hi: In what Order then were they written?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
In the Order following, viz. The Two Epiſtles to the Theſſalonians, the Firſt to Timothy, the Two Epiſtles to the Corinthians, the Epiſtle to Titus, the Epiſtle to the Romans, the Epiſtle to the Hebrews, to the Galatians, to the Epheſians, to the Philippians, to the Coloſſians, to Philemon, and
laſt of all his Second Epiſtle to Timothy a little before his Martyrdom.

p.hi: With which do we begin?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With the Epiſtle to the Romans.

div.head: ROMANS.

p.hi: VVHat doth this Epiſtle contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: This (as moſt of the reſt) begins with a Civil Salutation, and then proceeds in Points both Doctrinal and Practical.

p.hi: What are the Principal Points of Doctrine contained in it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Doctrine of Juſtification by Faith, without the Deeds of the Law, Chap. 3, 4. The Doctrine of Original Sin, Ch. 5. And (as ſome think) The Doctrine of Gods Election, Ch. 7. Together with the Rejecting the Jews, and Calling the Gentiles, to Chap. 12.

p.hi: What are the Points of Practice?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Duties of Piety towards God, and Juſtice towards men. Chap. 12. Of Obedienc to Authority, Chap. 13. Of Charity, by a mutual forbearance between Brethren in things of Indifferency, Ch. 14.

p.hi: How doth the Epiſtle conclude?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With ſome good Exhortations, and a Commendation to ſeveral Perſons eminent for their Chriſtian Profeſſion.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the ROMANS.

div.head: I CORINTHIANS.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: HOw doth this Firſt Epiſtle to the Corinthians begin?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
After the uſual Salutation,
Chap. 1,2,3 it begins with a Reproof of the Diſſentions which were among them in point of Religion; ſhewing that S. Paul's Preaching, though not in excellency of Speech,
Chap. 4 was in the Demonſtration of the Spirit and Power; ſhewing them alſo in what Account the Miniſters of God ſhould be among them, notwithſtanding the ſcorn which the Apoſtles then met with.

p.hi: What particular ſins doth the Apoſtle reprove among them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Inceſt committed by one,
Chap. 5 who married his Fathers Wife; for which they did not ſufficiently mourn; and therefore he took order for the man's puniſhment by Excommunication, in order to his Amendment, teaching them thereby how to deal with great Offenders.

p.hi: What elſe doth the Apoſtle reprove?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Fault common among them,
Chap. 6 upon every Trifle going to Law before Heathen Judges; and the Sin of Fornication, ſo much againſt a Man's own Body.

p.hi: How doth he then proceed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To diſcourſe about points of Marriage,
Chap. 7
in anſwer to ſome Queſtions which the Corinthians had ſent to him.

p.hi: What Anſwer doth he give to thoſe Queſtions?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That perſons ſhould marry to avoid Fornication; and when they are ſo married, that there ſhould be a mutual performance of all Duties between Husband and Wife; giving likewiſe particular Directions to the unmarried, to have them ſo continue, if capable of doing it; and to the Married, that they ſhould endeavour the Converſion of one another for their Good on both parts.

p.hi: Ʋpon what Point doth he next inſiſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Concerning Meats offered to Idols;
Chap. 8 that Chriſtian Liberty be not abuſed, but care taken for preventing any Offence to our Brethren.

p.hi: Hath he no Diſcourſe in this Epiſtle concerning the Miniſters of the Goſpel?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes;
Chap. 9 He ſheweth his own Liberty, and the Juſtice that every Miniſter hath to require a Livelihood upon his Employment; and that though himſelf was not chargeable to the Corinthians, yet he might have been ſo; only he was willing to become all things to all men, that by all means he might gain ſome.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What Doctrines doth he teach from what related to the Jews of old?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What doth he take notice of relating to Faults among them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Their Ʋndecent Carriage in Holy Aſſemblies, the wearing long Hair,
Chap. 11 and the Abuſe of the Lord's Supper.

p.hi: How doth he endeavour to rectifie this laſt fault?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By ſetting before them the Firſt Inſtitution of that Holy Sacrament, the Dangers of unworthy coming to it, and the means of Preparing for it by Self-Examination.

p.hi: Hath he no Diſcourſe concerning the Spiritual Gifts of the Holy Ghoſt?
p.label: Chap. 12

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He ſhews the Diverſity of them, but that they ſtill proceed from the ſame Spirit; and propounds their Serviceableneſs to the Church, by an Alluſion to the ſeveral Members of the Natural (as that is a Spiritual) Body.

p.hi: What doth he urge thence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The neceſſity of Charity,
Chap. 13 which he deſcribes, and ſhews its particular Properties; exalting it above all other Attainments and Gifts whatſoever.

p.hi: What other Doctrinal Point doth he write of?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: How doth he end the Epiſtle?
p.label: Chap. 16

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With directing a Charitable Collection for the Chriſtians in neceſſity; to be done by laying apart a proportion the Firſt day of each Week, according to every man's ability; and then gives his particular Salutations to ſeveral Friends.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Epiſt. to the CORINTHIANS.

div.head: II CORINTHIANS.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: IN what manner doth S. Paul begin this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
With an encouragement againſt Afflictions,
Chap. 1 by the Comforts uſually adminiſtred to Chriſtians under their Sufferings, propounding his own Experience, and avowing his ſincerity in Preaching among them.

p.hi: What other Subjects doth he treat of?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What particular Directions doth he give in point of Duty?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What way doth he take to prove himſelf above thoſe falſe Teachers?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By the Sufferings which he endured for the Goſpel's ſake (whereof he gives a particular account) and the Revelations he had.
Chap. 11

p.hi: What happened upon thoſe Revelations to keep him humble?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A very great Temptation (called a Thorn in the Fleſh,
Chap. 12 and a meſſenger of Satan to buffet him) which upon his Prayer, he was aſſiſted againſt.

p.hi: How doth this Epiſtle conclude?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
With threatning to be ſevere againſt incorrigible offenders;
Chap. 13 he encourageth them to try the Truth of their Faith, prays for the increaſe of their Strength and Love, and ſo pronounceth a Bleſſing upon them.

div.trailer: The End of the Second to the CORINTHIANS.

div.head: GALATIANS.

p.hi: VVHat is the Subſtance of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Apoſtle reproves the Galatians for being drawn from the True Doctrine of the Goſpel,
Chap. 1 declares the Miraculouſneſs of his Converſion; as a proof whereof, he mentions his former enmity to the Goſpel, and afterwards his oppoſing S.
Chap. 2 Peter for not walking according to the Rules thereof, that he might the more oblige the Jews.

p.hi: But what account gives he of his Apoſtleſhip to the World?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: This: That He and Barnabas were deſigned to Preach unto the Gentiles, as Peter, James and John were to the Jews.

p.hi: What Doctrine doth he particularly inſiſt upon in the Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Doctrine of Juſtification by Faith without the Deeds of the Law;
Chap. 3 proving it by the Promiſes made to Abraham; and ſhewing that the Law was but a Schoolmaſter to bring us unto Chriſt.

p.hi: How elſe doth he prove it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Two Alluſions.

p.hi: What is the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A comparing the Eſtate of Man under the Law,
Chap. 4 to the Eſtate of an Heir in his Minority, whilſt under Tutors and Governors; which was at an end when God ſent his Son into the World.

p.hi: What is the Second?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Comparing the Law which contained the Covenant of Works, to Hagar the Bond-woman, of whom came Iſhmael; and the Goſpel, which contains the Covenant of Grace, to Sarah the Free-woman, of whom came Iſaac the Son of the Promiſe; likening us and all Believers unto him.

p.hi: What Duties doth he urge?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A maintaining that Liberty which Chriſt hath beſtowed upon us,
Chap. 5 and a walking in the Spirit.

p.hi: How muſt that walking in the Spirit be known?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By not fulfilling the Luſts of the Fleſh; for the better Diſcovery whereof, he ſets down particularly what are the Luſts of the Fleſh, and what the Fruits of the Spirit.

p.hi: What other Duties are mentioned?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Tenderneſs towards an offending Brother;
Chap. 6 Liberality to the Preachers of the Word; Unweariedneſs in doing good, particularly in the exerciſe of Charity; and then he declareth how much he Gloried in ſuffering for Chriſt.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the GALATIANS.

div.head: EPHESIANS.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
VVHat is the Beginning of this Epiſtle to the EPHESIANS?
Chap. 1

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Apoſtle praiſeth God for their Election and Adoption, exhorting them to endeavour after a ſound knowledge of the Chriſtian Faith.

p.hi: What way doth he propound to bring them to this Knowledge?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He ſhews them their condition by Nature (as Children of wrath; and by Grace,
Chap. 2 as quickned from the Death of ſin in Chriſt;) teaching that this Bleſſing was beſtowed to make them full of good Works; to which they were the more encouraged by being made Fellow-Citizens (with the reſt of the Saints) of the Heavenly Jeruſalem.

p.hi: What elſe doth he declare unto them?
p.label: Chap. 3

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The great and myſterious Calling of the Gentiles, whereunto he effectually miniſtred, notwithſtanding his Troubles; and thereupon extols the great Love of Chriſt towards Mankind.

p.hi: What doth the Remainder of the Epiſtle contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Duties of Two ſorts; Perſonal and Relative.

p.hi: What are the Perſonal Duties.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Peace and Love urged upn the account of Chriſt's Love,
Chap. 4 in giving Himſelf, and afterwards a conſtant Miniſtry for the edification of his Church; a putting off the Old man, and putting on the New; an abſtaining from Lying, and Corrupt Communication,
Chap. 5 with all Anger and Maliciouſneſs; Fornication, Ʋncleanneſs, and Covetouſneſs; the walking circumſpectly, and avoiding Drunkenneſs; with Thankfulneſs to God, manifeſted by ſinging Pſalms.

p.hi: What are the Relative Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The ſubmiſſion of Wives to their Husbands, and the Love of Husbands to their Wives (by the example of that mutual carriage between Chriſt and his Church) the Obedience of Children to their Parents,
Chap. 6 and the Kindneſs of Parents to their Children; the Faithfulneſs of Servants to their Maſters, and the Gentleneſs of Maſters to their Servants.

p.hi: What is the Concluſion of all?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That every man in whatſoever capacity, ſhould put upon him the whole Armour of God for his Spiritual Defence, to enable him to withſtand all his enemies, and to ſtand in the evil day.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the EPHESIANS.

div.head: PHILIPPIANS.

p.hi: IN what manner begins this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
With a Profeſſion of S.
Chap. 1 Paul's Love to the Philippians, manifeſted by his conſtant Prayers for them; and a deſire that they ſhould not be too much concerned at his Sufferings, whereby the Goſpel of Chriſt was advantaged; complaining of ſome among them, who Preached Chriſt out of Strife and Contention.

p.hi: What doth he declare concerning himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A readineſs to Glorifie God either by Life or Death, which ſhould be moſt ſutable to his infinite Wiſdom.

p.hi: What particular Charge doth he lay upon them reſpecting his own Condition?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That whatſoever happened unto him, they ſhould live according to the Rules of the Goſpel, without being terrified by their Adverſaries, becauſe it was their eſpecial Priviledge not only to Believe in Chriſt, but likewiſe to ſuffer for him.

p.hi: What Exhortations doth he give them for the leading of their Lives?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He exhorts them to Humility,
Chap. 2 after the Example of Chriſt, who took our Nature upon him. 2. To an induſtrious working out their Salvation, from God's readineſs to aſſiſt them. And, 3. To a Blameleſs walking, conſidering themſelves to be the Children of God.

p.hi: What other things are mentioned?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A particular Caution againſt falſe Teachers,
Chap. 3
who would draw them to the obſervation of the Law; ſhewing his own Priviledges above others in that reſpect, which yet ſignified nothing to him in compariſon of the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt, which he endeavoured after; and a propoſal of his own Example for them to walk by.

p.hi: How did he urge this Propoſal?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By two Arguments; One drawn from the evil Lives of thoſe who were Enemies to the Croſs of Chriſt: Another, from the Heavenlineſs of his own Converſation, aſſuredly knowing that Chriſt from Heaven will appear to make even our very Bodies like unto his Glorious Body.

p.hi: What Duties are drawn from this Conſideration?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Five.
Chap. 4 1. A Stedfaſtneſs in the following him. 2. A Conſtant Rejoycing in God. 3. A Chriſtian Moderation. 4. An avoiding too much Carefulneſs for the things of this World, employing our ſelves to God by Prayer. 5. (To cloſe up all) a Following thoſe things which are True, Honeſt, Juſt, Pure, Lovely, and of Good Report.

p.hi: What particular occaſion of Thankfulneſs doth he take towards them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Upon the account of the Preſent they ſent to him in his Neceſſities.

p.hi: Was this done for his own ſake, or for theirs.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Not for his own want (becauſe he had learned in all conditions to be content)
but becauſe it teſtified their Fruitfulneſs under the Goſpel.

p.hi: What Promiſe doth he make them hereupon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: That God would ſupply all their Wants; to whom he gives Glory, and ſo concludes the Epiſtle.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the PHILIPPIANS.

div.head: COLOSSIANS.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: WHat is the Subſtance of the Epiſtle to the COLOSSIANS.

It begins with a Prayer for their Eſtabliſhment in Grace; a Deſcription of the True Chriſt, as the Head of the Church; and an Encouragement thereupon to receive, embrace, and continue ſtedfaſt in him.

p.hi: What is the beſt way propounded to do theſe things?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By being careful to avoid the Heathen Philoſophy, and the Legal Ordinances of Meats, Drinks, Days, and other Superſtitious Rites.

p.hi: What Duties doth the Apoſtle urge upon them?

sp.p:
The Duties of Heavenly-mindedneſs, Mortification, avoiding ſuch Sins, as Anger, Wrath and Malice; uſing themſelves to the exerciſe of Meekneſs, Forbearance, and Charity; to a Familiar converſing with the Word of Chriſt: Whence he proceeds to the Relative Duties between Husbands and Wives,
Chap. 4 Parents and Children, Maſters and Servants; giving ſome Directions for Continuance in Prayer, and walking wiſety toward the unconverted.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the COLOSSIANS.

div.head: I THESSALONIANS.

p.hi: WHat are the Contents of this Firſt Epiſtle?

sp.p: An Acknowledgment of the Theſſalonians Faith, and other Graces, with an Exhortation to walk worthy of that Grace which was given them, and an Expreſſion of that Love which the Apoſtle did bear to them.

p.hi: What Inſtructions doth he give them?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What elſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The not ſorrowing immoderately for the Dead in Chriſt, becauſe they were ſure of a Reſurrection and Eternal Life with God.

p.hi: What doth he take occaſion to diſcourſe of from this Subject?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Ʋncertainty of the Day of Judgment, giving a Caution of Conſtant Watchfulneſs, for fear they ſhould be taken upon a Surprizal.

p.hi: What other Duties follow?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To love their Teachers (as deſerving it upon the account of their Work) warning the unruly, comforting the feeble, ſupporting the weak, carrying patiently towards all, rendring Good for Evil, conſtant rejoycing, continual Prayer, Thankfulneſs in all things; not quenching the Spirit, nor deſpiſing Propheſies; and a retaining (among all things) that which is good; to which he adds the avoiding of all evil.

p.hi: How doth this Epiſtle end?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With a Prayer for their Through-Sanctification, a Declaration of God's Faithfulneſs, and a Deſire of their Prayers for him.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Epiſt. to the THESSALONIANS.

div.head: II THESSALONIANS.

p.hi: VVHat is the Beginning of this Epiſtle?

sp.p: It begins much like the Firſt, with giving Thanks for their Graces, and comforting them under their Troubles, by a conſideration of the ſure Reward which they ſhould have hereafter, and the certain Puniſhment of their Adverſaries at the Coming of Chriſt in his Power and Glory.

p.hi: Doth the Apoſtle give them no particular Caution?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Yes.
Chap. 2 For helping their ſtedfaſtneſs in the True Religion, he cautions that they ſhould not be be drawn aſide by the Inſtruments of the Man of Sin; whom he there deſcribes by his Pride and Irreligion.

p.hi: Is there no Judgment to fall upon thoſe who ſhould be drawn aſide?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Such an one, that their not receiving the Truth, ſhould expoſe them to the Embracing Lies for their future Condemnanation.

p.hi: What Particular Directions doth he give them?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The holding faſt thoſe Traditions which he he delivered to them; the praying to be delivered from wicked men; the avoiding thoſe who walked diſorderly, upon the account of ſuch as were Buſie Bodies among them;
Chap. 3 and a Perſeverance in welldoing.

p.hi: What elſe doth this Epiſtle contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: A Prayer of Peace for them from the God of Peace.

div.trailer: The End of the Second to the THESSALONIANS.

div.head: I TIMOTHY.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: WHo was Timothy to whom this Epiſtle was directed?

It was the Timothy whom S. Paul took to be his own Son, of whom we read, that his Mother was a Jeweſs,
Chap. 1 but his Father a Greek.

p.hi: Whereof doth this Epiſtle conſiſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Of certain Directions given to him for the managing his Office of a Preacher.

p.hi: What is the firſt thing wherein he was inſtructed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The right uſe and end of the Law, which is good, if a man uſe it lawfully.

p.hi: What occaſion doth the Apoſtle then take to ſpeak of himſelf?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To recount his own ſins; as a Blaſphemer, Perſecutor, and Injurious; whereby he extols the Great Mercy of God in his Converſion; and upon that, breaks out into a Thanksgiving to God for his Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
What particular Charges doth he give unto Timothy?
Chap. 2

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Theſe following. 1. The holding Faith and a good Conſcience, from the evil example of Hymeneus and Alexander, who had reliquiſhed them. 2. Prayer for all in
Authority; as a thing acceptable unto God, who deſires the Salvation of Mankind. 3. The Modeſty of Women in their Apparel.

p.hi: What elſe was charged upon him?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To know that the Office of a Biſhop of Souls (by giving his Character) was to be in every point unblameable,
Chap. 3 as alſo that of a Deacon, that they might be ſober and grave, with ability to Teach, both publickly, and by good example at home; and as they, ſo their Wives, to behave themſelves in Gravity and Sobriety.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Doth not the Apoſtle give Timothy ſome particular Caution?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
He cautions Timothy concerning the ſins of the latter Times;
Chap. 4 when Lies would be ſpoken, Marriage and Meats forbidden; of which he ſhews the great crime, and exhorts him unto the example of true Godlineſs, diligent Study, and taking heed both to Himſelf and his Doctrine.

p.hi: Having ſhewed his Duty as a Preacher, how is he taught to behave himſelf as a Ruler in the Church?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By certain Rules: As, 1.
Chap. 5 Not to reprove an Elder, but with great meekneſs. 2. To take care of Widows for their Maintenance, if old; if young (for fear of further Inconveniences) appointing them to Marry; ſhewing at what Age they ſhould be taken into the Churches Proviſion. 3. To provide
for the ſupport of thoſe Elders who were diligent in their Work for the Churches Good. And 4. The not Laying Hands ſuddenly on any man, nor being Partaker of the Sins of others.

p.hi: What further Directions doth he give?

sp.p: He teacheth Servants to be obedient to their Maſters, ſhews the Danger of immoderately loving the World, exhorts Timothy to fight the good fight of Faith, to the careful keeping his Commands; charging him alſo to teach Rich men Charity towards the Poor, for their own eternal Good; and ſo ends with Advice that he ſhould not concern himſelf with Nice and Fooliſh Queſtions.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Epiſtle to TIMOTHY.

div.head: II TIMOTHY.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: VVHat doth this Second Epiſtle to TIMOTHY contain?

The Apoſtle begins it with a Commendation of the excellent Faith in Timothy's Mother and Grandmother; exhorting him to ſtir up the Gift of God which was given him,
Chap. 2 to bear up under Perſecution, and to continue in the True Doctrine, as a good Souldier of Jeſus Chriſt.

p.hi: But beſides this as a Chriſtian, what is he exhorted to as a Preacher?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To Preach well, and not to give way to erroneous Opinions; ſuch as thoſe of Hymeneus and Philetus concerning the Reſurrection (as if already paſt) to flee youthful Luſts, and exerciſe the Graces of Meekneſs and Gentleneſs.

p.hi: What Account doth the Apoſtle give concerning the latter days?

sp.p: He gives an account of ſeveral ſins which ſhould then be rife; particularly a Pretence of Religion where there is nothing of it in reality.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: How is Timothy encouraged to avoid this and other Inconveniences?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By Three Arguments.

p.hi: What is the Firſt?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Paul's Example in the enduring of Afflictions?

p.hi: What is the Second?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The increaſe of thoſe wicked men in their Proceedings; which ſhould work upon him to continue in the good Doctrine he had learned.

p.hi: What is the Third?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Divine Inſpiration of the Scriptures, deſigned to render him, and every man of God accompliſhed for all Good Works.

p.hi: Are there no other Directions given him as a Preacher?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What Arguments are uſed to enforce this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ariſing of Falſe Teachers in the Church, to whom ſeveral perſons having itching Ears, would be enclined; and the drawing near of this Apoſtle's own Martyrdom, upon which he expected a Crown of Righteouſneſs.

p.hi: What elſe doth this Epiſtle contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some things particularly relating to the Apoſtles own Concern, but eſpecially an account of his firſt deliverance from Nero; whereupon he grounded an expectancy of God's delivering him from every evil way and work.

div.trailer: The End of the Second to TIMOTHY.

div.head: TITUS.

p.hi: WHat is the Subſtance of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
S. Paul having left Titus to order the affairs of the Church in Crete,
Chap. 1 gives him the Character of a good Biſhop; and recommends ſeveral things to his Care and Practice,

p.hi: What is the general Direction?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
To ſpeak the things which become Sound Doctrine.
Chap. 2

p.hi: What are the Particulars?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To teach the Duties of Sobriety, Temperance and Soundneſs of Faith in old men; a ſober behaviour in Aged Women; Obedience in the Younger Women to their Husbands, and Care of their Families; Diſcretion in the Younger men; Juſtice in Servants towards their Maſters.

p.hi: What Argument is uſed for theſe Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Grace of God appearing, which teacheth us to deny all Wickedneſs, and to live in Holineſs, Righteouſneſs and Sobriety.

p.hi: What elſe doth the Apoſtle command?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Obedience to Authority;
Chap. 3 the avoiding (in Titus himſelf) fooliſh Diſputes, and that he ſhould warn the Chriſtians to Carefulneſs in good Works.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſt. to TITUS.

div.head: PHILEMON.

p.hi: WHat is the Subſtance of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: S. Paul's Joy to hear of Philemon's good Life, whom he deſires to encourage Oneſiphorus in his Converſion, and receive him with all kindneſs, notwithſtanding his former faults, being willing to repay all things wherein Oneſiphorus might have done Philemon injury.

div.trailer: The End of PHILEMON.

div.head: HEBREWS.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: WHy is this called the Epiſtle to the HEBREWS?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe it was written to the Jews, ſo called from Heber, one of Abraham's Progenitors.

p.hi: Who was the Author of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several perſons are named, but it is generally believed to be S. Paul.

p.hi: Is there no Difference between this and the reſt of his Epiſtles?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes; not only in the Matter, but in the Form too.

p.hi: What is the Difference in point of Form?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The omitting that conſtant Salutation (the Beginning with his Name) which is uſed in all the others.

p.hi: May not this be the reaſon why it is ſuppoſed not to be his?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Moſt probably it may, from a Paſſage of his own: The Salutation of me Paul with mine own Hand, 2 Theſ. 3.17. which is the Token in every Epiſtle; So I write.

p.hi: Why was that Salutation omitted in this, rather than in any other Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Becauſe the Jews having a grand Prejudice againſt S. Paul, upon the account of his forſaking their Religion, might by ſeeing his Name in the Front, give leſs entertainment to the Doctrines delivered by him.

p.hi: What is the Subject-Matter of the Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Declaration of Chriſt in his Perſon and Offices;
Chap. 1 and thereby proving him to be the true Meſſias.

p.hi: Wherewith doth it begin?

sp.speaker: D.

p.hi: What follows next?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: An Account of his Offices, Prophetical, Prieſtly, and Kingly.

p.hi: What Account is there of his Prophetical Office?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: He is compared with, and preferred before MOSES, the Great Prophet of the Jews; Moſes being but a Servant, Chriſt a Son.

p.hi: What Duties are hereupon urged?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The great Duty of Faith, which the Iſraelites wanting, were not ſuffered to enter into God's Reſt, i. e. the Land of Canaan.

p.hi: What other uſe doth the Apoſtle make of this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Transferring his Argument from the Earthly, to the Eternal Reſt in Heaven, he engageth the Hebrews to Carefulneſs, leſt they ſhould fall ſhort of it, by quoting a Paſſage of David's; and from the particular Text declaring the Powerfulneſs of God's Word, and the Comfort we have in our Saviour.

p.hi: What Account is given of his Prieſtly Office?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In General, That he was not a Prieſt after the Order of Aaron, but of Melchizedek.

p.hi: How is this Melchizedek deſcribed?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: By his being King of Salem, and Prieſt of the moſt High God; (where Chriſt's Kingly Office is ſuggeſted) as alſo by his Relation (in point of Time) without Father without Mother, &c. and that He was the perſon to whom Abraham gave Tithes.

p.hi: What is the particular Argument which the Apoſtle draws from this?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That Perfection could not come by the
Levitical Prieſthood. 1. Becauſe then there had been no need of another Prieſt after the Order of Melchizedek; which he confirms by our Saviour's being of another Tribe, viz. of Judah. 2. Becauſe thoſe Prieſts died, but He (according to the Oath of God) endureth for ever. 3. Becauſe thoſe Prieſts were Many, he was but One. 4. Becauſe they were Imperfect, he was Perfect.

p.hi: What Inference is drawn from hence?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A Conviction to the Jews,
Chap. 8 That the Levitical Prieſthood was abrogated, and the Firſt Covenant come to an end; which is proved by an Inſtance in ſeveral Rites and Ceremonies of the Law, which could ſignifie nothing of themſelves, but as Types, were made good in Chriſt.

p.hi: In what things doth the Apoſtle eſpecially inſtance?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
In the Prieſt's accompliſhing the Service of God by entring into the Holy Place with Blood,
Chap. 9 which Chriſt after his Bloody Sacrifice, had compleated, entring then into Heaven, the Holy Place made without Hands, and in their daily offering Sacrifices for themſelves and the People, which he did at once when he made himſelf a Sacrifice for Sin.

p.hi: What doth he then take occaſion to ſhew?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Weakneſs of the Law,
Chap. 10 and all its Services, in reſpect of thoſe which are ordained under the Goſpel, with the neceſſity of Obedience to Chriſt, as being above
Moſes, by the dreadful Puniſhments inflicted upon thoſe who would not comply with Moſes his Inſtitution?.

p.hi: What is the Reſult of all he had delivered?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The real need and excellency of Faith, encouraging all men unto it.

p.hi: How doth he proſecute that Subject?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By a Deſcription of Faith,
Chap. 11 as The Subſtance of things hoped for, the Evidence of things not ſeen; the great Commendation it procured thoſe who exerciſed it, and how neceſſary it was for the pleaſing God.

p.hi: What Perſons doth he name eminent for Faith?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Abel, Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Jacob, Joſeph, Moſes, Rahab, Gideon, Barak, Jephthah, Samſon, David, Samuel, and the Prophets?

p.hi: What did they do by their Faith?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: They did wonderful things, and endured great Sufferings.

p.hi: What doth the reſt of the Epiſtle contain?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some eſpecial Duties to be performed by all who profeſs themſelves Chriſtians.

p.hi: What Duties doth he mention?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: 1. Chap. 12 The following the Pattern of thoſe Worthies in ſuffering, conſidering above all, the Example of Chriſt Jeſus; and then that this ſuffering is deſigned for the Portion of God's Children. 2. The following Peace and Holineſs. 3. The not failing of the Grace of God.

p.hi: What other Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: 1. Chap. 13 The Continuance of Brotherly Love. 2. Hoſpitality. 3. The Sympathizing with our Brethren in Affliction. 4. Contentedneſs in their Condition. 5. Obedience to their Spiritual Guides and Rulers. 6. Offering up the Sacrifice of Praiſe. And laſtly, Not omitting charitably to diſpenſe towards the Neceſſities of their Chriſtian Brethren.

p.hi: How doth this Epiſtle conclude?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: With an Hearty Prayer, that God through Chriſt, would make them perfect in every good Work to do his Will.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle to the HEBREWS.

div.head: S. JAMES.

p.hi: WHat are the Principal Parts of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Apoſtle beginning with an Exhortation to Patience under Croſſes,
Chap. 1 and an Application to God for Spiritual Wiſdom where it is wanting; proceeds to clear God's Innocency, from them who would make him the Author of Sin, by declaring that the Prevalency of Temptations is from our ſelves.

p.hi: What Duties doth he urge?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Carefnlneſs to Practiſe the Word of God delivered unto them, by the unprofitableneſs of meer hearing without doing; comparing it to a man's beholding himſelf in a Glaſs, and preſently forgetting his own Face.

p.hi: What is the Second Duty?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
A not reſpecting Rich men more than the Poor,
Chap. 2 and proving the Law to command an Obedience to it in its full extent.

p.hi: What Doctrine doth he then inſiſt upon?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The unprofitableneſs of a pretended Faith without Works, cleared by the Inſtances in Abraham and Rahab.

p.hi: What elſe doth he inſtruct us in?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Several things in the Three following Chapters.

p.hi: What Particulars in the Third Chapter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Vanity of arrogant reproving others;
Chap. 3 ſhewing the guilty exceſſes of the Tongue, and the peaceableneſs of a true heavenly Wiſdom.

p.hi: What in the Fourth Chapter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The Danger of loving the World, and of Envy and Pride; the neceſſity of Submiſſion to God, Repentance and Humiliation; the evil of Backbiting, and promiſing our ſelves long Life.

p.hi: What in the Fifth Chapter?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
The Danger of Covetouſneſs,
Chap. 5 Grudging againſt one another; the Good of Patience under Afflictions, by the Example of
Job; a charge to forbear all Prophane Swearing; a Direction for Sick Perſons to have the PRAYERS OF THE CHƲRCH, and make a Mutual Confeſſion of their Sins; and the great Charity of Reducing a Straying Brother from his Errors.

div.trailer: The End of the Epiſtle of S. JAMES.

div.head: I. S. PETER.

p.hi: VVHat are the Contents of this Epiſtle?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
S. Peter (after a Salutation to the Converted Jews,
Chap. 1 and acknowledging Gods mercy in providing them an Eternal Inheritance in Heaven;) Propounds the Excellency of the GOSPEL MYSTERIES, and thence takes occaſion to preſs ſeveral Duties upon them.

p.hi: What are theſe Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Some Perſonal, ſome Relative, intermingled with one another.

p.hi: What are the Perſonal Duties?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: 1. Chap. 2 The laying aſide all things of Malice, and whatſoever is a Breach of Charity. 2. The Abſtaining from Fleſhly Luſts, with the leading an Honeſt Life towards the Gentiles for Gods Glory. 3. The Submiſſion to Authority.

p.hi: What follow after theſe?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Relative Duties between Servants and Maſters, between Husbands and Wives.

p.hi: How doth the Epiſtle return to the former Sort?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
By teaching the Duties of Ʋnity, and Patience under Sufferings; from the Example of Chriſt ſuffering for Sinners; the avoiding a prophane Converſation,
Chap. 4 whatſoever Offence our care to do ſo gives to the World, and the maintaining Hoſpitality.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What particular Advice is given as to the Preaching of the word?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
That they ſhould diligently feed the flock of God;
